channel.title: Planet Money but it's all episodes

item.title: Episode 753: Blockchain Gang
item.description: Charlie Shrem went to prison. While he was there, he thought up a better way to move money behind bars. Now, he's out and trying to sell his idea to international investors.

item.title: Episode 436: If Economists Controlled The Borders
item.description: What would the perfect immigration system look like? We ask three economists and get three very different answers. (None of which include building a wall.)

item.title: Episode 752: Eagles vs. Chickens
item.description: Picture an organic farm, with thousands of free-range chickens roaming wide-open land. Now picture it from above, from the vantage of a soaring bald eagle. It's an all-you-can-eat buffet.

item.title: Episode 751: The Thing About That Border Tax
item.description: Over the next few months, we're going to explain President Trump's economic plans. Today: a totally new idea for corporate taxes. What's the plan, what's the theory behind it, and does it work?

item.title: Episode 750: Retraining Day
item.description: When an American loses his/her job to trade, there's program to help. It's been around for decades. It makes a lot of sense. It is a generous program. And almost nobody's heard of it. But why?

item.title: Episode 632: The Chicken Tax
item.description: President Trump talks about putting tariffs on foreign cars. But there are already tariffs on auto imports and one got there because of chickens in Germany. This is how trade barriers tend to spread.

item.title: Episode 749: Professor Blackjack
item.description: Ed Thorp started his career teaching math at MIT. Then he slid sideways into blackjack, changed the game forever, and set his sights on Wall Street investing. He changed that forever too.

item.title: Episode 748: Undoing Obama
item.description: Congress writes laws, but the president makes the rules that put the laws in action. President Obama's staff has been scrambling to lock in rules before Trump takes the helm. But will they stick?

item.title: Episode 747: The Man Who Sued Iran
item.description: When Steve Flatow's daughter was killed in a terror attack, he wanted someone to pay. His target was the Iranian government. His quest would pit him against both Iran and the White House.

item.title: Episode 577: The Kansas Experiment
item.description: A Republican governor lives the dream. He cuts taxes dramatically in his state and he promises good times ahead. But the good times do not come.

item.title: Episode 746: Wall Street Goes To Vegas
item.description: Wall Street traders and Las Vegas gamblers have a lot in common. But when a Wall Street firm set up shop taking Vegas bets, both sides got a surprise.

item.title: Episode 443: Don't Believe The Hype
item.description: People are talking about how the Dow Jones Industrial Average is about to hit a new record: Twenty thousand. We have a pretty strong opinion about the Dow. We think you should ignore it.

item.title: Episode 745: The Rest Of The Story, 2016 Edition
item.description: It's time for an annual Planet Money tradition--we revisit some of our favorite stories from the past year, and see what's changed since we turned off our mics.

item.title: Episode 744: The Last Bank Bailout
item.description: The man who ran the last bank bailout has a plan to prevent the next one.

item.title: Episode 587: Jubilee! (?)
item.description: There's an idea that dates back at least to biblical times. That there should be a moment when debts are forgiven. Its called a jubilee. One country tried it.

item.title: Episode 743: 50 Ways to Leave Your Union
item.description: Today on the show, two unions separated by 200 years, an ocean and an exit clause. The United States has no exit clause. It led to civil war. Europe, on the other hand, has Article 50.

item.title: Episode 742: Making Bank
item.description: On today's show, how a band of medieval warrior monks sworn to poverty got into the banking business and changed the way we think about money forever.

item.title: Episode 592: Bell Wars
item.description: A special holiday episode about the epic, decades-long feud between the two companies that make just about every handbell in the world.

item.title: Episode 741: Amy and Steve vs. Facebook
item.description: The story of a court case. On one side, the best lawyers money can buy. On the other, a night school lawyer who had never argued a case before. The outcome could affect everyone on the Internet.

item.title: Episode 740: Burnout
item.description: All types of companies are struggling with burnout. Many try to fix it. Most of them fail. One exception: A 26-year-old call center manager, with stress balls and costumes in her arsenal.

item.title: Episode 739: Finding The Fake-News King
item.description: We track down a fake-news creator in the suburbs, uncover his empire of fake-news sites, and get him to tell us his secrets.

item.title: Episode 534: The History Of Light
item.description: In this show: How we got from candles made out of cow fat to as much light as we want. The history of light is the history of economic growth — of things getting faster, cheaper, and more efficient.

item.title: Episode 738: The Russian Rodeo
item.description: Russia's latest ambition: To build a steak empire. On today's show, a fourth-generation American cowboy teaches Russian ranchers how to make American-style steaks. Some things get lost in translation.

item.title: Episode 737: 17 Deals In 17 Minutes
item.description: We go on a madcap dash through discounts, bargains and tough tradeoffs. Like the headline says: We bring you stories of 17 deals in just 17 minutes (not counting the intro, the ad, or the credits).

item.title: Episode 736: Messy Nobel
item.description: What happens when a creativity guru meets the winner of this year's Nobel Memorial Prize in economics? You get life lessons in making art, and negotiating contracts.

item.title: Episode 574: The Buffalo Talk-Off
item.description: The story of a guy who tried to make something of himself by getting into a rough business. And the story of a time when the world went wild for debt.

item.title: Episode 735: President Trump
item.description: Candidates promise all kinds of things. But once they get into office, it's not always possible to carry through on them. We ask, can Trump do the things he's pledged to do?

item.title: Episode 734: The Trump Indicators
item.description: Donald Trump is our president elect. We look at three economic indicators to see what they can tell us about a Trump presidency.

item.title: Episode 733: A Trunk Full of Truffles
item.description: Truffles are a lumpy, smelly fungus. They're also one of the most coveted foods in the world. Why are they so expensive? And why are people willing to pay so much for them?

item.title: Episode 413: Our Fake Candidate Meets The People
item.description: On today's show, Planet Money's economist-approved fake candidate makes his first ads. Then we nervously watch to see what a focus group thinks of them.

item.title: Episode 732: Bad Form, Wells Fargo
item.description: Banks like Wells Fargo have a weapon that can destroy an employee's career: A form. A long, boring form most people don't even know exists.

item.title: Episode 387: The No-Brainer Economic Platform
item.description: Behold the Planet Money economic platform, crafted by brilliant economists of all stripes, and pure poison to any politician who embraces it.

item.title: Episode 731: How Venezuela Imploded
item.description: Venezuela has just about every economic advantage a country could ask for: fertile land, good climate, educated population, and oil, lots and lots of oil. So how did it go so wrong?

item.title: Episode 730: Self Checkout
item.description: A doctor treating psychiatric patients in an emergency room created the first self-checkout machine in his spare time. Now he can't stand self checkout. So we take him shopping.

item.title: Episode 729: When Subaru Came Out
item.description: Subaru's sales had been slumping for years. So the car company took a big risk and targeted a group of consumers that just about everyone else was ignoring.

item.title: Episode 627: The Miracle Apple
item.description: How we got from mealy, nasty apples to apples that taste delicious. The story starts with a breeder who discovered a miracle apple. But discovering that apple wasn't enough.

item.title: Episode 728: The Wells Fargo Hustle
item.description: We take you inside the headquarters of Wells Fargo bank. It's a place where a bunch of young, stressed-out workers were rewarded for doing some very bad things.

item.title: Episode 521: The Town That Loves Death
item.description: On today's episode, we'll take you to a place where dying has become acceptable dinner conversation. A place that also happens to have the lowest healthcare spending of any region in the country.

item.title: Episode 727: You Asked For It, Again
item.description: New show! You asked us questions about the economy and oddities in your world. We answer.

item.title: Episode 726: Terms of the Debate
item.description: We made an audio glossary for the confusing economic jargon that came up during the first presidential debate.

item.title: Episode 725: Trade Show
item.description: On today's show: The fight over free trade. Come for the man who dreamed of world peace through trade. Stay for Robert Smith in the mean streets of Seattle.

item.title: Episode 555: Why Is The Milk In The Back Of The Store?
item.description: We test two competing theories, from a food writer and an economist. Are customers being forced to walk through the store or is it just practical to keep the milk at the back?

item.title: Episode 573: Why Textbook Prices Keep Climbing
item.description: Prices of new textbooks have been going up like crazy — faster than food, cars, even healthcare. On today's show: Why textbooks have gotten so expensive.

item.title: Episode 724: Cat Scam
item.description: The internet was supposed to get rid of middlemen--but instead they are taking over the global economy.

item.title: Episode 566: The Zoo Economy
item.description: If you're a zoo or aquarium and you want a new animal, you don't use money to get it. You have to find another way. In this episode, we investigate: How many mackerel is a flock of puffins worth?

item.title: Episode 723: The Risk Farmers
item.description: There is a mystery in many poor countries. Why don't farmers specialize and grow more food? Two economists with very different theories go head to head to find out.

item.title: Episode 532: The Wild West Of The Internet
item.description: For decades, most websites ended in either .com, .net, or .org. But a few years ago, everything changed.

item.title: Episode 722: The New Telenovela
item.description: One telenovela actress-turned-executive decided to create a new kind of drama. Her work changed the landscape of Spanish language TV--and of all TV.

item.title: Episode 721: Unbuilding A City
item.description: Why is it so hard to knock down 17 vacant houses in a shrinking city?

item.title: Oil #5: Imagine A World Without Oil
item.description: Last of five episodes. We follow the Planet Money oil to a gas station. And we ask: What would our world look like if there were no fossil fuels?

item.title: Oil #4: How Oil Got Into Everything
item.description: Fourth of five episodes. Oil is in our sneakers, our clothes, and the computer or phone you're using right now. On today's show: The story of the man who made it happen.

item.title: Oil #3: How Fracking Changed the World
item.description: Third of five episodes. The Planet Money oil faces a test, we sell it, and we meet the man who set off the fracking boom in America.

item.title: Oil #2: The Price Of Oil
item.description: Second of five episodes. Oil is priced down to the penny, and the price changes every day. Who sets that price?

item.title: Oil #1: We Buy Oil
item.description: We're getting into the oil business. We go to Kansas, and negotiate with a preacher to buy 100 barrels of crude.

item.title: Episode 524: Mr Jones' Act
item.description: There's an obscure law that governs just about anything that travels by ship in the U.S. — bananas, hairdryers, gasoline, even people. Economists do not like it. But it just won't go away.

item.title: Episode 715: The Sewing Robot
item.description: Building a robot that can sew even simple clothes is surprisingly hard. A retired professor in Atlanta thinks he's solved the problem. It could bring clothing manufacturing back to America.

item.title: Episode 548: Project Eavesdrop
item.description: The computer or phone that you use knows a lot about you. It knows your secrets — and it might be giving them away.

item.title: Episode 714: Can A Game Show Lose?
item.description: Crafting a TV game show is a balancing act. Producers have to carefully calibrate the rules, the drama and the prizes just right. Sometimes they get it way wrong.

item.title: Episode 576: When Women Stopped Coding
item.description: A lot of computing pioneers were women. For decades, the number of women in computer science was growing. But in 1984, something changed.

item.title: Episode 712: I Want My Money Back
item.description: Three stories of people getting their money back — or trying to. From a hospital, a scammer, and the ever-exciting global bond market.

item.title: Episode 711: Hooked on Heroin
item.description: Scoring a fix is cheap and today's heroin is strong. But that's just part of the reason why America got hooked. Today on the show, we trace the roots of America's heroin epidemic.

item.title: Episode 710: The Brexit Break-Up
item.description: Brexit is like a breakup. So today a divorce story in two acts. We hear from both sides: The people who voted to leave, and the Europeans being left.

item.title: Episode 709: The Quiet Old Lady Who Whispers "Fair Use"
item.description: Where is the line between being inspired by somebody's creative work and stealing it?

item.title: Episode 708: Bitcoin Divided
item.description: Bitcoin was supposed to revolutionize the way money works. But the thing people love about it may be destroying it.

item.title: Episode 707: Brexit
item.description: What just happened in the UK? And what's coming next?

item.title: Episode 538: Is A Stradivarius Just A Violin?
item.description: How much of a brand is real? How much is in our heads?

item.title: Episode 706: Water's Worth
item.description: If your country's main export is water, what happens when your wells run dry?

item.title: Episode 583: Cow Noir
item.description: There is a crime wave in the West right now. Cattle rustling — stealing cattle — is on the rise. The crime is as old as America, and it's making a big comeback.

item.title: Episode 705: The Muscle Patents
item.description: Two bodybuilders go at it over a Stanford University patent. And we dive in to make sense of it.

item.title: Episode 536: The Future Of Work Looks Like A UPS Truck
item.description: Technology means that no matter what job you have — whether you're alone in a truck on an empty road or sitting in a cubicle in front of a computer — your company can now track everything you do.

item.title: Episode 704: Open Office
item.description: This episode is for everyone who's ever had to ask their coworkers to quiet down or walk laps of the office to make a private phone call. Today on the show: We meet the man who stole your office door.

item.title: Episode 463: How To Get A Country To Trust Its Banks
item.description: It's something you can see on every day and on every block in most major cities. But in Myanmar, a country that was cut off from the rest of the world for decades, an ATM is a small miracle.

item.title: Episode 703: How To Hide A Million Dollars In Plain Sight
item.description: How do you secretly stash away a million dollars? One way is to hide the money in plain sight, right in the heart of New York City. Today's show: the case of who owns Apartment 5B.

item.title: Episode 217: The Art Of Living At The Poverty Line
item.description: Meet a single mother who makes $16,000 a year and managed to fund a vacation at a Caribbean resort with an interest-free loan from one of the world's largest banks.

item.title: Episode 366: How To Make It In The Food Truck Business
item.description: In New York City, more than 5,000 food trucks and carts compete for the business of hungry office workers. And finding the right spot to set up shop can mean the difference between fortune and ruin.

item.title: Episode 701: A Bank Without Interest
item.description: To serve Muslim customers, a bank in Michigan tried to comply with both U.S. regulations and Islamic law. One problem: Islamic law prohibits charging interest.

item.title: Episode 430: Black Market Pharmacies And The Spam Empire Behind Them
item.description: On today's show, we open up some of those annoying pharmaceutical spam emails and find out who's clicking to buy herbal viagra? Also, what happens when they do?

item.title: Episode 700: Peanuts and Cracker Jack
item.description: Beer. Water. Pretzels. It takes effort, strategy, and some serious lungs to sell expensive junk food at a baseball game. Meet the hot dog vending legend of Fenway Park.

item.title: Episode 699: Why Did The Job Cross The Road?
item.description: To get to the other side...where there are millions of dollars in tax breaks.

item.title: Episode 698: The Long Way Home
item.description: Housing subsidies are often given out through a lottery. But why do we let random chance decide who gets help with the rent? We don't do that for food stamps or health care, so why housing?

item.title: Episode 417: Lance Armstrong and The Business of Doping
item.description: In this episode, we consider a world where everybody cheats, and where you can't win unless you game the regulators: Professional cycling.

item.title: Episode 697: Help Wanted
item.description: When you're an employer looking at a giant stack of resumes, you have to find some way to quickly narrow the field. How do you do that fairly? And what happens when your good intentions backfire?

item.title: Episode 468: Kid Rock Vs. The Scalpers
item.description: We talk to Kid Rock about how he tried to cut scalpers out of the business — and still sell cheap tickets to his shows.

item.title: Episode 696: Class Action
item.description: The modern class action was created on a typewriter in the back of a car. (Sort of.) Now, thousands of these lawsuits are filed every year. How did we get here? Is this really a good way to do things?

item.title: Episode 695: Put A Chip On It
item.description: Credit cards with chips in them have been around for four decades. So why is America only getting them now? And now that they are here, why are so few places using them?

item.title: Episode 694: The Gun That Wouldn't Shoot
item.description: Imagine a safer kind of gun. Imagine a company with a plan to build it. Imagine customers ready to buy it. Imagine what could go wrong. A whole lot.

item.title: Episode 562: A Mall Divided
item.description: A California mall straddles the border between two cities — and the minimum wage is higher on one side.

item.title: Episode 693: Unpayable
item.description: Puerto Rico is part of the United States, but not one of the United States. And this limbo status has brought a world of economic trouble.

item.title: Episode 403: What Can We Do With Our Shell Companies?
item.description: And how can we meet our fake shareholder and fake director?

item.title: Episode 692: The Secret Life Of Line 24
item.description: On today's show, we tell the stories of a few mysterious lines on IRS form 1040 — the basic tax form. In its own, maddening way, the 1040 is a great American document.

item.title: Episode 691: The Great Unbundling
item.description: There's a revolution underway in the world of cable TV--more and more people are getting rid of it. And there are some unforeseen consequences when we cut the cord and go our separate ways.

item.title: Episode 690: All In
item.description: We talk to a professional poker player who lost on the first day of poker's most famous tournament--but went on to get a huge payout. Turns out there's a game behind the game.

item.title: Episode 390: We Set Up An Offshore Company In A Tax Haven
item.description: In this show, we dive deep into the world of hiding money. We look for the easiest place to shelter a bank account and set up our own shell company in an offshore tax haven. Good times.

item.title: Episode 689: A Hedge Fund, A Country, And A Big Sailboat
item.description: Argentina decided that it could take on the world. They had a bunch of debt and said, 'we're not paying.' Then a group of hedge funds took the entire country to court.

item.title: Episode 418: How The Government Set Up A Fake Bank To Launder Drug Money
item.description: One day in the early 1990s, a man walked into the U.S. embassy in Ecuador. He said he had information on how to go after some of most powerful drug traffickers in the world.

item.title: Episode 688: Brilliant vs. Boring
item.description: A million-dollar bet pits a bunch of really smart money managers against the simplest investment idea in the world.

item.title: Episode 687: Buy This Passport
item.description: Most of us don't think of citizenship as a product. It's something more: It's part of who you are. On today's show, we look at what happens when citizenship goes up for sale.

item.title: Episode 686: If Elected President
item.description: Today, we bring you the future as dreamt up by presidential candidates. Also: sober economists poking holes in the candidates' dreams.

item.title: Episode 424: How Much Is A Firefighter Worth?
item.description: Firefighters don't go to fires as much as much as they used to. Yet the fire department is still set up the same way. What should change?

item.title: Episode 685: Larry vs. The IRS
item.description: A lot of people dream of not paying their taxes. Larry Williams scoured the fine print of IRS code, talked to lawyers, settled on a plan, then just stopped paying taxes.

item.title: Episode 684: The Return Of The Colonel
item.description: There's a secret war going on inside every franchise. At KFC, it all goes back to a guy with a white beard and a black string tie: Colonel Harland Sanders.

item.title: Episode 683: Our Valentines
item.description: Regret. Self-loathing. Jealousy. Happy Valentine's Day! We bring you little stories that we love so much, we wish we had thought of them ourselves.

item.title: Episode 466: DIY Finance
item.description: He has thousands of dollars stashed around his house. She's part of an informal savings club. And Miguelo Rada has a whole bank in his pocket.

item.title: Episode 682: When CEO Pay Exploded
item.description: Politicians have argued for decades that CEOs should earn less money. But there was a moment in the 1990s when CEO pay suddenly shot up. What happened?

item.title: Episode 681: The Oil Kingdom
item.description: For years, Saudi Arabia has been living off one resource and one resource only: Oil. But now, the price of a barrel has plummeted, and the country is scrambling to adapt.

item.title: Episode 680: Anatomy Of A Scam
item.description: You've seen these ads: "You can work from home and get rich. It's easy. Call this number!" So, what happens when you respond?

item.title: Episode 679: You Asked For It
item.description: We ponder the origins of money, the economics of Santa, and the business of cemeteries. Why? Because you asked.

item.title: Episode 678: Auction Fever
item.description: We uncover the secrets of the auction world. There is conniving. There are tricks. Also: Hydraulic hammers.

item.title: Episode 283: Why Do We Tip?
item.description: According to one theory, we tip because we feel guilty, not because we want better service.

item.title: Episode 677: The Experiment Experiment
item.description: How much of published scientific research is false? Scientists are trying to figure it out.
If those had been the winning Powerball numbers, this would have been our last show. Instead, the story of the oldest lottery we could find and of the man who outsmarted the odds.

item.title: Episode 675: The Cost Of Crossing
item.description: Sneaking people across the U.S.-Mexico border is a well established, booming business. Today on the show, we meet a businessman and a client in the evolving industry of human smuggling.

item.title: Episode 15: Delicious Cake Futures
item.description: On today's Planet Money, the complex economy of one elementary-school lunchroom.

item.title: Episode 674: We Cooked A Peacock
item.description: In the 1600s, a good spice rub was the ultimate display of wealth. People would risk their lives for a sack of cloves. On today's show, we cook a recipe from the spice trade days.

item.title: Episode 673: The Rest of the Story, 2015 Edition
item.description: Not every story has an ending. Sometimes after we finish a podcast and send it to you, the facts change, a new chapter unfolds. Today on the show, we update some of our favorite episodes from 2015.

item.title: Episode 672: Bagging a Birkin
item.description: There are people with Birkin bags, and there are the rest of us. Today on the show: the elaborate, upside-down strategy that has kept a $60,000 purse the "it" bag for 30 years.

item.title: Episode 671: An Insider Trader Tells All
item.description: Today on the show: A man who got caught insider trading explains everything — what he did, how he did it, and why. Though he's still struggling with that last one.

item.title: Episode 670: The Santa Suit
item.description: A lawsuit over a Santa suit. It's a window into countless hidden fights that shape the stuff we buy.

item.title: Episode 590: The Planet Money Workout
item.description: Today on the show: The mind games that gyms play with you. From design to pricing to free bagels, gyms want to be a product that everyone buys, but no one actually uses.

item.title: Episode 669: A or B
item.description: These days A/B testing is everywhere. It's shaped almost every website, some stores and even some school lessons. Today, the most meta episode ever. Planet Money A/B tests a show about A/B testing.

item.title: Episode 668: Frank Sinatra's Mug
item.description: When you die you can pass on your money, your house. But your image--what you look and sound like--that's trickier. Today on the show: How Frank Sinatra made his image, and maybe yours, last forever.

item.title: Episode 667: Auditing ISIS
item.description: What happens when ISIS takes over your city? Today on the show: We meet a man who lived in ISIS controlled territory. He talks about paying taxes, where he kept his money and a $50 candy bar.

item.title: Episode 216: How Four Drinking Buddies Saved Brazil
item.description: Two decades ago, shoppers in Brazil would run ahead of the worker who raised prices every day. Inflation was crazy. Today on the show: How four economists --who were also drinking buddies-- fixed it.

item.title: Episode 666: The Hoverboard Life
item.description: The hottest toy this holiday season has no identifiable logo, no main distributor, and no widely agreed upon name. Today, we seek out the origin of the hands-free, two wheeled, self-balancing scooter.

item.title: Episode 665: The Pickle Problem
item.description: A national network of food banks couldn't figure out how to get the right food to the right place at the right time. So they tried a bold experiment: the free market.

item.title: Episode 664: The Great Inflation
item.description: For much of the 70s inflation was bad. Prices rose at over 10 percent a year. Nothing could stop it — until one powerful person did something very unpopular. Today's show: How we beat inflation.

item.title: Episode 416: Why The Price Of Coke Didn't Change For 70 Years
item.description: The answer includes a half a million vending machines, a 7.5 cent coin, and a company president who just wanted to get a couple lawyers out of his office.

item.title: Episode 663: Money Trees
item.description: Each time you travel, you burn fossil fuels. That hurts the environment. Some people say you can plant a bunch of trees to offset the damage. Is that for real? We investigate carbon offsets.

item.title: Episode 505: A Locked Door, A Secret Meeting And The Birth Of The Fed
item.description: A 70-year-old man with a bad cold and many mistresses, a nation that's ambivalent about a central bank, and a secret meeting on an island. Today on the show: The origin story of the Federal Reserve.

item.title: Episode 662: OMG TPP
item.description: The text of the Trans-Pacific Partnership isn't secret anymore. We dove in. From tariffs for waterproof overalls to copyright rules, we tell you what we found. Also, a way countries can get around it.

item.title: Episode 661: The Less Deadly Catch
item.description: Today on the show, how an economic fix took the deadliest job in America and made it safer. And why a lot of people are mad about it.

item.title: Episode 660: The T-Rex In My Backyard
item.description: There's a boom going on for dinosaur bones, a veritable gold rush for fossils buried in the badlands of North Dakota, Wyoming and Montana. Today on the show: the T-Rex that started it all.

item.title: Episode 518: Your Organs, Please
item.description: How do you get someone to sign up as an organ donor? Today on the show: The story of one woman who found a way by partnering with one of the more hated American institutions.

item.title: Episode 659: How To Make $3 Trillion Disappear
item.description: After the financial crisis, the Fed created over $3 trillion. To undo this, they have a new trick. Today on the show, how the Federal Reserve plans to make that money disappear.

item.title: Episode 550: When Salaries Aren't Secret
item.description: What would it be like if everyone at your office knew what everyone else earned? On today's show, we hear about a company where salaries aren't secret.

item.title: Episode 658: Strike One
item.description: On today's show: The birth of unions as we know them. It's a story that includes, among other things, bravery, cunning, and auto-part projectiles flung out of giant sling shots.

item.title: Episode 657: The Tale Of The Onion King
item.description: Vince Kosuga farmed onions. Then he tried trading them on the market, too. He made millions. Today on the show: How trading got so out of hand that the Chicago River flowed with America's onions.

item.title: Episode 656: Bubblelicious
item.description: Things are booming in Silicon Valley. Maybe too booming. But economists say you can't call it a bubble until it goes POP. Today on the show: We find three bubbly barometers that could signal a bust.

item.title: Episode 564: The Signature
item.description: The signature. We put it on checks, contracts, credit cards. It's supposed to say, "This is me." But where did the idea come from? And why are we still using it?

item.title: Episode 655: Pay Patients, Save Money
item.description: We shop around when we get a plane ticket or buy a couch. But we spend thousands of dollars on health care without shopping around. What happens if we pay patients when they choose the cheaper option?

item.title: Episode 654: When The Boats Arrive
item.description: In 1980, thousands of Cuban refugees suddenly arrived in Miami and started looking for work. On today's show: What happened next. And what it tells us about the migration crisis in Europe today.

item.title: Episode 653: The Anti-Store
item.description: Today on the show: How Price Club and its imitators changed the way we shop. And how a new company is taking what Price Club started to new extremes.

item.title: Episode 386: The Power of Free
item.description: Everybody likes free. But free can be dangerous. On today's show, what happens when you take something that was free and give it a price. That's a highly risky move and the damage can be enormous.

item.title: Episode 652: The Hydrox Resurrection
item.description: Hidden in the trash heap of commerce there is buried treasure. Abandoned brands, even beloved, trusted brands, are waiting to be claimed and reborn. Today on the show: a cookie comeback.

item.title: Episode 651: The Salmon Taboo
item.description: Today on the show: How hard could it be to get a nation of sushi lovers to try raw salmon?

item.title: Episode 650: The Scariest Thing In Hollywood
item.description: One Hollywood director leaves the world of big budget blockbusters for something even more lucrative: low budget Hollywood.

item.title: Episode 649: China, China, China
item.description: What's going on in China? Is the second largest economy in the world about to come crashing down?

item.title: Episode 648: The Benefits of Bankruptcy
item.description: When Roddey Player's business started heading south, he did everything he could to avoid the big failure: bankruptcy. But what's painful for Roddey might just be the secret weapon of the U.S. economy.

item.title: Episode 200: The Moonshine Stimulus
item.description: We travel to Warm Springs to find out if the rumors are true: Did FDR really buy moonshine during Prohibition? Did he violate the Constitution he had sworn to protect?

item.title: Episode 647: Hard Work Is Irrelevant
item.description: Patty McCord helped create a workplace at Netflix that runs more like a professional sports team than a family. If you're not up to scratch, you're off the team. Is this the future of work?

item.title: Episode 502: The Afterlife Of A T-Shirt
item.description: When used American clothes are donated to charity, they begin a second life of sorting, refitting, and lots of travel. We trace used American T-shirts to a used-clothing market in Nairobi, Kenya.

item.title: Episode 646: Why Can't We Bet On Elections?
item.description: In Las Vegas you can bet on all kinds of stuff. One thing you can't bet on: elections. But why? Not long ago, no election was too sacred to wager on, not even the pope's.

item.title: Episode 500: The Humble Innovation At The Heart Of The Global Economy
item.description: Our women's Planet Money T-shirt got to you thanks to an overlooked innovation that's essential to the modern global economy. The innovation: a big, metal box.

item.title: Episode 645: How To Stop An Asteroid
item.description: Some smart people say we should be doing more to protect the earth from asteroids. The technical issues are relatively easy. The economics — figuring out who's going to pay — are much harder.

item.title: Episode 497: The Sisters Who Made Our T-Shirt
item.description: Like lots of other clothes, the men's Planet Money T-shirt was made in Bangladesh. On today's show, we travel to Bangladesh and visit two sisters who made our shirt.

item.title: Episode 644: How Much Does This Cow Weigh?
item.description: We wanted to understand an eerie phenomenon that drives everything from the stock market to the price of orange juice. So we asked you to guess the weight of a cow.

item.title: Episode 496: Where The Planet Money T-Shirt Began
item.description: We made a T-shirt, and followed it every step of the way. First step: a high-tech cotton farm.

item.title: Episode 643: The Taxi King
item.description: Gene Freidman built a taxi empire in New York City. Now his empire is starting to crumble.

item.title: Episode 642: The Big Red Button
item.description: The big question surrounding automation isn't just about economics or technology. It's also about psychology. How do designers make us comfortable with something that can be really scary?

item.title: Episode 641: Why We Work So Much
item.description: The world economy is more productive than ever before. A lot of people could work fewer hours and still meet their basic needs. But we don't. Why?

item.title: Episode 640: The Bottom Of The Well
item.description: On today's show: the screwed-up economics of drought, and why the rational thing to do in California right now is use more water.

item.title: Episode 639: Where To Hide €50,000, And Other Stories From Greece
item.description: On a visit to Greece, we talk to a guy who found an ingenious place to hoard his cash, a government-protected milk peddler, and a would-be olive oil tycoon.

item.title: Episode 638: Tweak The World
item.description: Today on the show: We're going small. We ask some of the smartest people we know what little thing they would change to improve the world.

item.title: Episode 288: Manufacturing The Song Of The Summer
item.description: The story of the secret battle to create the song of the summer — the music industry's holy grail.

item.title: Episode 637: The Last Euro In Greece
item.description: Greece's monetary system is in crisis right now, and the government is closing the financial pipes. The effects are widespread and weird.

item.title: Episode 363: Why People Do Bad Things
item.description: We sit down with a psychologist and a mortgage broker who committed large-scale fraud to try to figure out why respectable people commit fraud.

item.title: Episode 636: Yes Or No
item.description: What do you do when your country's future is put in your hands? On today's show: The referendum in Greece.

item.title: Episode 635: Trade Deal Confidential
item.description: Trade deals like the Trans-Pacific Partnership are often negotiated in secret. On today's show, negotiators tell us what happened when they were locked in a hotel for days and told to hash out a deal.

item.title: Episode 478: The Raisin Outlaw
item.description: A farmer wanted to sell all his raisins, but the federal government said no. So he took it to the Supreme Court.

item.title: Episode 634: Worst Case Scenario
item.description: We ask three economists: Is there some falling anvil that's about to crush the economy?

item.title: Episode 633: The Birth And Death Of The Price Tag
item.description: The price tag is a fairly recent invention. And it's already on its way out.

item.title: Episode 632: The Chicken Tax
item.description: How the American auto industry is built on a trade dispute over frozen chicken parts.

item.title: Episode 631: The Long Run
item.description: Stories about a $50,000 loophole, what neighborhoods mean for kids, and what the Six Million Dollar Man would cost today.

item.title: Episode 630: Free Parking
item.description: The story of a 24-year-old kid and the idea he thought would reduce congestion, cut greenhouse gasses and make urban life easier for everyone. Instead, it brought him nothing but trouble.

item.title: Episode 628: This Ad's For You
item.description: In the early 1960s, Tom Burrell became the first black man in Chicago advertising. Today on the show, the story of how he changed the way people think about ads and how advertising thinks about us.

item.title: Episode 627: The Miracle Apple
item.description: Today on the show, how we got from mealy, nasty apples to apples that taste delicious. The story starts with a breeder who discovered a miracle apple. But discovering that apple wasn't enough.

item.title: Episode 626: This Is The End
item.description: Machines have been taking jobs forever. In the past, when jobs disappeared, new ones were created. But is this time different?

item.title: Episode 625: The Last Job
item.description: What if robots did all the work? In today's show, we imagine a world without jobs.

item.title: Episode 624: I, Waiter
item.description: We go out for pizza and meet the latest group of workers getting replaced by machines: servers.

item.title: Episode 623: The Machine Comes To Town
item.description: In Greenville, SC, the best job option isn't to compete against the robots, but to make friends with them.

item.title: Episode 622: Humans vs. Robots
item.description: If you aren't already worried about being replaced by a robot, maybe you should be. Today on the show, three races pit humans against machines.

item.title: Episode 621: When Luddites Attack
item.description: Today on the show, the true story of the Luddites.

item.title: Episode 620: Why Batteries Suck
item.description: While most technology is getting smaller and cheaper, batteries still suck. Today on the show, we learn exactly why, and meet some of the people trying to make batteries better.

item.title: Episode 372: How Do You Decide Who Gets Lungs?
item.description: You're not allowed to buy and sell organs. So doctors created a different system. Today on the show: how do you decide who gets lungs?

item.title: Episode 619: The Free Throw Experiment
item.description: Casinos are worried that young people aren't interested in playing slots or other games of luck. They're turning to games that require skill, like basketball.

item.title: Episode 399: Can You Patent A Steak?
item.description: We visit the workshop of a meat inventor, who came up with Steak-Umm and KFC's popcorn chicken. And we try to figure out what meat inventors tell us about patents and innovation.

item.title: Episode 618: The Square Deal
item.description: In the early 1900s, the president of the largest shoe company in the world tried to create a Utopia for his workers. He called his big experiment in welfare capitalism: The Square Deal.

item.title: Episode 617: How Do You Feel?
item.description: Today on the show: how a bunch of rational economists try to deal with our feelings. And the story of a man who came up with five simple questions that he hoped would predict the future.

item.title: Episode 616: How Solar Got Cheap
item.description: Just a few years ago, solar power was an expensive luxury for the environmentally conscious. Now it's a good deal for lots of people. How did solar power get so cheap, so fast?

item.title: Episode 361: The Matzo Economy
item.description: How do you make money manufacturing a dry, bland cracker that a tiny percentage of the population eats just one week a year?

item.title: Episode 615: A 12-Year-Old Girl Takes On The Video Game Industry
item.description: A 12-year-old girl discovers it can cost a lot more to play video games as a girl. Today on the show: video game economics and a sixth-grade smackdown.

item.title: Episode 614: Two Radio Guys Walk Into A Bar
item.description: We go on stage at a comedy show and read a bunch of weird economics jokes. We bombed.

item.title: Episode 613: Trash!
item.description: There's an economic line that separates recyclables from trash. And that line has been moving a lot lately.

item.title: Episode 443: Don't Believe The Hype
item.description: Last week Apple was officially added to the Dow Jones Industrial Average. But just because Apple's in the club now, doesn't mean the Dow is a great measure of the economy.

item.title: Episode 612: The Indicator Strikes Back
item.description: Look at the numbers today, and things seem promising for the economy. Jobs and home prices are up. But look under the hood, and you see that in a lot of ways the crisis is still with us.

item.title: Episode 611: Community
item.description: Only one in three students finish community college—even if money is not the problem.

item.title: Episode 610: The Prisoner's Solution
item.description: Today on the show, a businessman goes to prison, and decides he is going to disrupt the biggest captive market in America.

item.title: Episode 609: The Curse Of The Black Lotus
item.description: Faced with an asset bubble, the creators of Magic: The Gathering came up with a plan—a plan to once and for all conquer the science of bubbles, and make a collectible toy that could live forever.

item.title: Episode 608: Shorters Gonna Short
item.description: We look at the ten most shorted stocks out there, to see what this list tells us about human nature and the economy. Plus, we end our shorting experiment.

item.title: Episode 517: The Fastest Growing, Least Popular Airline In America
item.description: Spirit Airlines is one of America's fastest-growing airlines. It's also among the least popular airlines in America. How can one airline be both things at once?

item.title: Episode 607: Captive Market
item.description: Kidnapping is big business in Nigeria. One man analyzed the industry, to find its weak points and better protect the people he loved.

item.title: Episode 606: Spreadsheets!
item.description: The electronic spreadsheet transformed entire industries. But its effects ran deeper than that.

item.title: Episode 605: 'What Goes Up'
item.description: In 1929, one man correctly predicted the great stock market crash, for totally the wrong reason.

item.title: Episode 604: Hey Big Spender
item.description: Today, one man at the center of a high stakes negotiation, a group of poker players try to give their money away and that thing everyone loves to hate: airplane baggage fees.

item.title: Episode 603: A Rose On Any Other Day
item.description: The logistical miracles and wild risks behind getting red roses to your doorstep on Valentine's Day.

item.title: Episode 510: The Birth of the Minimum Wage
item.description: It's a story of exploding bakeries, a blue eagle, and a guy who may or may not have been drunk.

item.title: Episode 602: Big Weed
item.description: Pot is now legal in some states, but on the federal level, it's illegal. The legal gray area means many banks in the U.S. won't even give pot businesses checking accounts.

item.title: Episode 601: The Chocolate Curse
item.description: The world is running out of chocolate. But a plant scientist in Ecuador has come up with a solution. But if you love chocolate, you might not like it.

item.title: Episode 600: The People Inside Your Machine
item.description: Today on the show, we visit the place where regular people compete to do tiny tasks, sometimes for pennies.

item.title: Episode 599: The Invisible Wall
item.description: A man goes looking for the invisible wall that traps poor people in poverty. Finding it almost gets him killed.

item.title: Episode 598: The Very First Short
item.description: There have been short sellers throughout history. Today, the story of a man who was the very first short seller. The first person to bet that a stock will go down. It doesn't go well for him.

item.title: Episode 597: We're Short America
item.description: Today on the show, we ignore the advice of some very smart people and bet against something people love.

item.title: Episode 253: Gold Standard, R.I.P.
item.description: On today's Planet Money: The gold standard and the Great Depression. It's the latest in our gold series.

item.title: Episode 252: The Gold Standard
item.description: We visit the respected finance writer (and charming curmudgeon) James Grant. He makes the case for going back on the gold standard.

item.title: Episode 596: Johnny Mnemonic's Secret Door
item.description: How one man stumbled into a flaw in Apple's operating system and found a way to hack into the phone you might have in your hands right now. The iPhone 5s.

item.title: Episode 222: The Price Of Lettuce In Brooklyn
item.description: And what it has to do with how big your raise is next year.

item.title: Episode 595: The Rest Of The Story, 2014 Edition
item.description: On today's show, we follow up on a few of our stories from 2014.

item.title: Episode 594: Board Games
item.description: On today's show: The story of two guys who tried to cut the pay of a CEO at a small, pneumatic tool company.

item.title: Episode 593: Who Had The First Job?
item.description: People have always worked. But the thing we think of today as a job — is actually a recent invention. On today's show, we go in search of the very first modern job.

item.title: Episode 592: Bell Wars
item.description: Today on the show, a special holiday episode about the epic, decades long feud between the two companies that make just about every handbell in the world.

item.title: Episode 591: War? What War?
item.description: Today on the show, the revolution in Ukraine was supposed to make the country a better place for Western investment. But it ended up sparking a war that is scaring that investment away.

item.title: Episode 590: The Planet Money Workout
item.description: Today on the show, the mind games that gyms play with you. From design to pricing to free bagels, gyms want to be a product that everyone buys, but no one actually uses.

item.title: Episode 589: Hello, I'm Calling From La Mafia
item.description: On today's show: What it's like to live and work in the most dangerous country in the world.

item.title: Episode 588: The Technology Tango
item.description: How customers use a piece of technology can change what the product is. And what the product is can change the business model. It's a constant dance between customers and sellers.

item.title: Episode 587: Jubilee! (?)
item.description: Iceland is trying out an idea from the Bible. What happens, when you just wipe debt clean?

item.title: Episode 271: A City On The Moon
item.description: How did a barren, icy island become a thriving, modern economy?

item.title: Episode 586: How Stuff Gets Cheaper
item.description: Today on the show, we visit a company where people's job is figuring out how to make stuff get cheaper.

item.title: Episode 585: Chasing The Dread Pirate Roberts
item.description: Imagine a marketplace completely free of government interference. A place with no contracts, no courts and no regulations. Except for one pirate, the Dread Pirate Roberts.

item.title: Episode 474: The North Korea Files
item.description: We got a stack of letters from American citizens who wanted to buy stuff from North Korea. On today's show, we try to figure out who sent the letters, and why.

item.title: Episode 584: What The LeBron?
item.description: Some guys have figured out how to sell Nike sneakers for a better price than Nike. And that's fine with the company.

item.title: Episode 583: Cow Noir
item.description: There is a crime wave in the West right now. Cattle theft, or as they call it in Oklahoma, cattle rustling, is on the rise. The crime is as old as America, and it's making a big comeback.

item.title: Episode 582: Guarding The Secret Path
item.description: There's a tiny town on the border between Ivory Coast and Liberia. On one side, Ebola is raging. On the other side, people are doing everything they can to make sure not a single case arrives.

item.title: Episode 581: Free Money
item.description: There's a term in economics, arbitrage, that basically means free money. It's a risk-free way to buy low and sell high. Arbitrages are nearly impossible to find. Today, two guys who say they did.

item.title: Episode 580: The Other Side Of The Pump
item.description: Gas prices have been falling since early summer, but not everyone is happy about it. Today, stories about the people who get the oil out of the ground.

item.title: Episode 579: Is The NCAA An Illegal Cartel?
item.description: In big-time college football or basketball, money is everywhere. Coaches are paid millions. Schools make tens of millions. But it's against the rules for schools to pay athletes.

item.title: Episode 578: How To Steal A Million Barrels Of Oil
item.description: Stealing oil takes a global system. Lots of people are in on it - small time crooks, criminal bosses, oil tankers owners and corrupt officials.

item.title: Episode 400: What Two Pasta Factories Tell Us About The Italian Economy
item.description: Italy is two countries — and two economies — in one.

item.title: Episode 577: The Kansas Experiment
item.description: A Republican governor lives the dream. He cuts taxes dramatically in his state, and he promises good times ahead. But the good times do not come. Now he's fighting for his political life.

item.title: Episode 576: When Women Stopped Coding
item.description: A lot of computing pioneers, the ones who programmed the first digital computers, were women. For decades, the number of women in computer science was growing. But in 1984, something changed.

item.title: Episode 381: Why It's Illegal To Braid Hair Without A License
item.description: Licensing laws are supposed to protect the public. But they also raise prices and make it harder for people to find work.

item.title: Episode 575: The Fondue Conspiracy
item.description: The popularity of fondue wasn't an accident. It was planned by a cartel of Swiss cheese makers, which ruled the Swiss economy for 80 years.

item.title: Episode 574: The Buffalo Talk-Off
item.description: Today on the show: The story of a guy who tried to make something of himself by getting into a rough business. And the story of a time when the world went wild for debt.

item.title: Episode 573: Why Textbook Prices Keep Climbing
item.description: Prices of new textbooks have been going up like crazy — faster than food, cars, even healthcare. On today's show: why textbooks have gotten so expensive.

item.title: Episode 572: Jewelers, Futurists And Whistleblowers
item.description: Today on the show: Stories about the secrets of jewelry stores, the problem with World's Fairs and a law signed by Abraham Lincoln that's being used today to go after the largest banks in the world.

item.title: Episode 571: Why Raising Money For Ebola Is Hard
item.description: On today's show, the psychology of giving. Charities raised $1.4 billion to help rebuild Haiti after the earthquake. But when something like Ebola happens, so far, people look the other way.

item.title: Episode 477: Waiting For Robot Nannies
item.description: More than half of all Japanese women quit their jobs after giving birth to their first child. That's more than double the rate in the U.S., and it's a problem for Japan's economy.

item.title: Episode 570: The Fine Print
item.description: Today on the show, we read our homeowners insurance policy — and get to the bottom of all that fine print that nobody every reads.

item.title: Episode 569: How To Divide An Imaginary Pie
item.description: Alex Blumberg is starting a podcasting business, but he needs a partner. Today on the show, Alex searches for that partner. Hewlett-Packard, Ben & Jerry, and now there's Blumberg and ...

item.title: Episode 568: Snoops, Hackers And Tin Foil Hats
item.description: We pay for an amazing amount of stuff on the internet with our personal data. Today on the show: The story of two people trying to create online services that won't collect any data at all.

item.title: Episode 567: Getting Unstuck
item.description: For years now, the economy has been kind of stuck. The unemployment rate is getting better, but slowly. Household incomes have been falling. Today, stories of two people trying to get unstuck.

item.title: Episode 566: The Zoo Economy
item.description: Zoo animals are different than most possessions, because zoos abide by a fundamental principle: You can't sell or buy the animals. Today: What do you do in a world where you can't use money?

item.title: Episode 565: The Story Of Alibaba
item.description: The company has transformed China. Also: It means anyone anywhere can build almost anything.

item.title: Episode 564: The Signature
item.description: Today on the show: the signature. It's supposed to say, "This is me." But where did it come from. And why are we still using it.

item.title: Episode 563: "I Was Wrong"
item.description: Today, we talk to smart, thoughtful people about times they got things really, really wrong.

item.title: Episode 562: A Mall Divided
item.description: A California mall straddles the border between two cities — and the minimum wage is higher on one side of the mall.

item.title: Episode 485: What's Your Major?
item.description: The most lucrative majors lead to jobs with salaries over $100,000 a year. The least lucrative lead to salaries of around $30,000.

item.title: Episode 561: How The Future Looked 50 Years Ago
item.description: Today on the show, the future as seen from the 1964 World's Fair. And how the future actually turned out.

item.title: Episode 560: Hunting For The Hundreds
item.description: Most U.S. cash is in $100 bills, but you rarely see them. Today on the show, where in the world are all the $100s? And what are they being used for?

item.title: Episode 559: Detroit's Water Bill
item.description: Today on the show, how a bankrupt city is dealing with the most basic of problems — how to get people to pay their bills.

item.title: Episode 451: Why Some People Love Tax Day
item.description: On today's show, we look at a huge, often overlooked, surprisingly interesting corner of the tax code: The Earned Income Tax Credit.

item.title: Episode 558: Spending Big Money To Fight Big Money
item.description: A half a billion dollars. A Harvard professor. And, maybe, the end of campaign finance as we know it.

item.title: Episode 557: Doing Business Like A Refugee
item.description: Today on the show: Why most countries in the developing world won't let refugees work. And why Uganda is trying something different.

item.title: Episode 556: Some Assembly Required
item.description: Today we build our show from three short Planet Money stories. We look at when a dollar is not worth a dollar; publishing without a publisher; and, of course, Ikea.

item.title: Episode 555: Why Is The Milk In The Back Of The Store?
item.description: Today on the show, two big theories to answer a little question: Why is the milk in the back of the store?

item.title: Episode 554: How The Burrito Became A Sandwich
item.description: On today's show, how something as simple as a sandwich sales tax ends up a complicated list of definitions, exemptions and confusion. And what that tells us about the tax code in general.

item.title: Episode 553: The Dollar At The Center Of The World
item.description: Today on the show, how a New Hampshire hotel filled with boozing economists saved the global economy.

item.title: Episode 552: Blockbusters, Bombs And The Price Of A Ticket
item.description: A ticket to an unpopular movie in an empty theater costs the same as a ticket to a sold-out blockbuster. Why?

item.title: Episode 551: The Case Against Patents
item.description: Today on the show, we talk to two guys who say we should get rid of patents. If someone has an idea, anyone else is free to steal it.

item.title: Episode 471: The Eddie Murphy Rule
item.description: On today's show, we answer one of the most important questions in finance: What actually happens at the end of Trading Places?

item.title: Episode 550: When Salaries Aren't Secret
item.description: What would it be like if everyone at your office knew what everyone else earned? On today's show, we hear about a company where salaries aren't secret.

item.title: Episode 549: A Teenager's Guide to Doing Business in North Korea
item.description: Today on the show: how a 13-year-old girl built a business in North Korea.

item.title: The Real Price Of College
item.description: There's a huge gap between the sticker price for college tuition and the price students actually pay. On today's show, we try to figure out why.

item.title: Episode 548: Project Eavesdrop
item.description: Planet Money's Steve Henn invited a couple computer guys to tap his internet connection for a week. He was shocked by how much they discovered.

item.title: Episode 547: How To Punish A Bank
item.description: When banks do bad things, the financial cops can fine them or get them to admit guilt. Now, they might try something brand new. Today on the show: how to punish a bank.

item.title: Episode 546: Fear, Negativity And Pawn Shops For The Rich
item.description: Today on the show: stories about bored traders, a bank that charges customers to deposit money, and pawn shops for the rich.

item.title: Episode 545: The Blue Pallet
item.description: People have moved stuff on pallets for a long time. And for basically 50 years, no one in the U.S. really improved on it. Until they did.

item.title: Episode 544: The M&M Anomaly
item.description: One hungry reporter goes on a quest to find out why his package of Peanut Butter M&M's weighs 0.06 ounces less than a package of Milk Chocolate M&M's.

item.title: Episode 472: The One-Page Plan To Fix Global Warming
item.description: Tax carbon emissions. That's basically the whole plan.

item.title: Episode 543: A World Without Banks
item.description: There's this big idea floating around right now. The idea is this: get rid of banks. Don't make them safer. Don't make them smaller. Just get rid of them.

item.title: Episode 542: Can An Economy Be Too Good?
item.description: A recent report out of Europe says that Germany is doing really well. And says that doing really well can actually be a big problem, if you're on the Euro.

item.title: Episode 541: Who Owns The Air?
item.description: Aviation companies want to fly drones along your street and over your backyard. But legally they may not have the right. You own your house, but what about the space above it?

item.title: Episode 540: Great Expectations
item.description: Today on the show we have three radio stories for you about the strange ways people think about the future.

item.title: Episode 539: What's A Penny Worth?
item.description: Today on the show: The penny. And the strange spot it occupies in our economy. It's worth almost nothing, but not quite.

item.title: Episode 337: The Secret Document That Transformed China
item.description: In 1978, a group of farmers in a Chinese village wrote a contract and hid it in the roof of a hut. They were afraid the document might get them executed. Instead, it transformed the Chinese economy.

item.title: Is A Stradivarius Just A Violin?
item.description: How much of a brand is real? How much is in our heads?

item.title: Episode 537: Hold The Music, Just The Lyrics Please
item.description: If you use the words to someone else's song to make money-- do you have to give the songwriter some of that money?

item.title: Episode 536: The Future Of Work Looks Like A UPS Truck
item.description: Technology means that no matter what job you have — whether you're alone in a truck on an empty road or sitting in a cubicle in front of a computer — your company can now track everything you do.

item.title: Episode 535: Humanitarians, For A Price
item.description: On today's show, we visit a country with almost no government, but a lot of entrepreneurs who have become humanitarians for profit.

item.title: Episode 534: The History of Light
item.description: On today's show: How we got from candles made out of cow fat to as much light as we want. The history of light is the history of economic growth, of things getting faster, cheaper, and more efficient.

item.title: Episode 444: New Jersey Wine
item.description: Lou Caracciolo is trying to make high-quality wine from grapes he grows in New Jersey. But Jersey wine already has a reputation — and fancy isn't it

item.title: Episode 533: Why Cars From Europe and the US Just Can't Get Along
item.description: On today's show, we talk to designers and car company executives about one of the biggest technical challenges they face: making all the different governments happy.

item.title: Episode 532: The Wild West Of The Internet
item.description: Most websites end in .com, .gov or .edu. But a bunch of new domains have just been added. Now there's .ninja, .bike, .plumbing and .cool. In all, over 1,000 new top-level domains will be added.

item.title: Episode 531: The Tough, The Sweet And The Nosy
item.description: On today's show, we head to some of the cheating-est places on earth to bring you tales from some of the roughest, toughest tax collectors around.

item.title: Episode 530: Marijuana, Law School, And Centuries Of Inequality
item.description: After today's show, you'll be ready to design a tax on marijuana, pick a law school and discuss the hottest new book in economics (without having to read a page).

item.title: Episode 529: The Last Mile
item.description: People love to complain about their internet service, but most of the time, they can't switch. Today on the show: Why isn't there more competition?

item.title: Episode 436: If Economists Controlled The Borders
item.description: What would the perfect immigration system look like? We asked three economists to dream big.

item.title: Episode 528: Money, Work and TV
item.description: On today's show: secret deals, Machiavellian negotiation tactics and the minimum wage.

item.title: Episode 527: The Amazing Shrinking Economy Might Stop Shrinking
item.description: Greece, the country we all worried might take down the euro and Europe, may finally be ready to turn around.

item.title: Episode 526: A Planet Money War
item.description: The US is responding to Russian tanks, artillery and special forces with its own weapon: money.

item.title: Episode 525: Trouble Inside A Babysitting Economy
item.description: Today, we tackle the big question of how to pull an economy out of a recession by going...small.

item.title: Episode 435: Why Buying A Car Is So Awful
item.description: Why millions of Americans still haggle with car dealers in person, one brand at a time.

item.title: Episode 524: Me and Mr. Jones
item.description: There's an obscure law that governs just about anything that travels by ship in the US - bananas, hairdryers, gasoline, even people.

item.title: Episode 523: The Fight Over Ukraine's Gas Bill
item.description: A grandmother's gas bill can explain a lot about the conflict between Ukraine and Russia.

item.title: Episode 522: The Invention Of 'The Economy'
item.description: If you asked someone on the street 100 years ago, "How's the economy doing?" They wouldn't have had any idea what you were talking about.

item.title: Episode 521: The Town That Loves Death
item.description: In today's episode, we'll take you to a place where dying has become acceptable dinner conversation. A place that also happens to have the lowest healthcare spending of any region in the country.

item.title: Episode 520: Duke's $30,000 Tuition Discount
item.description: Duke says it costs $90,000 a year to provide an undergraduate education. The school opens its books and tells us where all that money is going.

item.title: Episode 519: Wall Street's Image Problem
item.description: The financial crisis left Wall Street with an image problem. Yet recruits continue to sign up. What's driving today's young bankers and how is that changing?

item.title: Episode 518: How To Bore Someone Into Donating An Organ
item.description: Annoyed? Preoccupied? Great, now donate an organ. How Michigan may have solved a supply problem with one question.

item.title: Episode 517: The Fastest Growing, Least Popular Airline In America
item.description: It's cheap to fly on Spirit Airlines, but you have to pay extra for perks. And by perks, we mean a bottle of water or space in the overhead bin.

item.title: Episode 427: LeBron James Is Underpaid
item.description: LeBron James is the most underpaid professional athlete in the world today. On today's show, we explain why that might actually be good for him.

item.title: Episode 516: Why Paying $192 For A 5-Mile Car Ride May Be Rational
item.description: Leaving money on the table. It's a concept economists hate and one that the app Uber is trying to solve. But is this startup really solving a problem by charging you more for your ride to work?

item.title: Episode 515: A Bet Over Bitcoin
item.description: A big-time venture capitalist thinks bitcoin will change the world. A prominent writer thinks bitcoin is going to disappear. On today's show, they make a long-term bet on bitcoin's future.

item.title: Episode 514: How Bernanke Set Off Tomato Protests In Brazil
item.description: Tomato inflation in South America. Coal start-ups in Indonesia. Fat Cats on Wall Street. What do they all have to do with each other?

item.title: Episode 513: Dear Economist, I Need A Date
item.description: On today's show, economist and author, Tim Harford, applies economic theory to your questions about love, sex and dating.

item.title: Episode 512: Can Mezcal Save A Village?
item.description: In rural Oaxaca, there are basically no jobs. Two cousins have a dream to change that.

item.title: Episode 511: Rule Breakers
item.description: On today's show: Three stories about people who, intentionally or not, found themselves breaking the rules.

item.title: Episode 510: The Birth Of The Minimum Wage
item.description: It's a story of exploding bakeries, a blue eagle, and a guy who may or may not have been drunk.

item.title: Episode 509: Will A Computer Decide Whether You Get Your Next Job?
item.description: To hire new employees, some companies are paying less attention to resumes and more attention to data — and the data are leading to some surprising findings.

item.title: Episode 282: Inside The Credit Card Black Market
item.description: If you know the right people — and if you can get other criminals to vouch for you — you can go online and buy huge bundles of stolen credit cards. As it turns out, Planet Money knows the right people.

item.title: Episode 508: A Bet On The Future Of Humanity
item.description: A famous biologist predicts overpopulation will lead to global catastrophe. An economist disagrees — and challenges the biologist to a very public bet.

item.title: Episode 507: The Rest Of The Story
item.description: On today's show, we follow up on a few of the stories we did in 2013.

item.title: Episode 506: Bell Wars
item.description: On today's show: a decades-long feud between two big bell companies, located right down the road from each other.

item.title: Episode 504: Can Hospitals Save Money By Making Doctors Squirm?
item.description: We sit in on a tense conversation where doctors argue about why it's so hard to start surgery on time. And we hear what happens when you change the way hospitals and doctors get paid.

item.title: Episode 503: Adding Up The Cost Of The Planet Money T-Shirt
item.description: We open up the books and explain how much went to cotton, how much went to workers in Bangladesh, and how much went places we would never have imagined.

item.title: Episode 502: The Afterlife Of A T-Shirt
item.description: The U.S. exports over a billion pounds of used clothing every year — and much of that winds up in used clothing markets in sub-Saharan Africa.

item.title: Episode 501: A Shirt, A Meat Grinder And The Book Of Everything
item.description: On today's show, the Planet Money T-shirts arrive at the Port of Miami. But they're not quite here yet.

item.title: Episode 500: The Humble Innovation At The Heart Of The Global Economy
item.description: On today's show: the story of an often-overlooked innovation that's essential to the global economy. The innovation is a box. A big, metal box.

item.title: Episode 499: Richard Nixon, Kimchi And The First Clothing Factory In Bangladesh
item.description: "We asked ourselves, 'What the hell do we want?'" Answer: "We need employment. We need dollars."

item.title: Episode 498: The Last T-Shirt In Colombia
item.description: In the latest installment of our T-shirt series, we move from Bangladesh to Colombia — and we see an entirely different world.

item.title: Episode 497: Love, Betrayal And The Planet Money T-Shirt
item.description: On today's show: the lives of two sisters and the rise of the garment industry in Bangladesh.

item.title: Episode 496: Where The Planet Money T-Shirt Began
item.description: After years of planning and months of production, our shirts are here.

item.title: Episode 495: The Weird Inner Workings Of The Payday Loan Business
item.description: On today's show, we go looking for the people making these loans and find a bizarre online marketplace where people's personal financial information is bought and sold. Plus, we talk to state regulators about why it's so hard to police high interest lending happening online.

item.title: Episode 494: What Happens When You Just Give Money To Poor People?
item.description: A study discovers what happens to farmers in Kenya after they get a windfall. Also: giving money to thieves and drug addicts in a country that's much worse off than Kenya.

item.title: Episode 462: When Patents Hit the Podcast
item.description: Jim Logan did not create the technology to podcast. He himself is not a modern-day podcaster. But he claims to have the patent on podcasting. On today's show, he says all the people out there podcasting today, owe him money.

item.title: Episode 493: What's A Bubble? (Nobel Edition)
item.description: On today's show, we talk to Eugene Fama and Robert Shiller, who shared this year's economics Nobel. Shiller is a famous explainer of bubbles; Fama is a famous bubble skeptic.

item.title: Episode 377: Can Lincoln Be Cool Again?
item.description: Lincolns used to be the coolest cars in the world. On today's show, we hear how Lincoln is trying to regain its former glory.

item.title: Episode 492: M. Erb's Amazon Empire
item.description: Michael Erb has reviewed more than 800 products on Amazon — everything from a telescope to facial wipes. Why does he do it?

item.title: Episode 391: The Anti-Addiction Pill That's Big Business For Drug Dealers
item.description: It's totally legal. So why do lots of addicts have to buy it on the street?

item.title: Episode 407: A Mathematician, The Last Supper And The Birth Of Accounting
item.description: Jane Gleeson-White, author of Double Entry: How the Merchants of Venice Created Modern Finance, tells us the story of how one mathematics book changed business across the planet.

item.title: Episode 491: The Debt Ceiling, Obamacare And Welfare
item.description: On today's show: Three ripped-from-the-headlines stories from Planet Money.

item.title: Episode 490: The Real Economy Of Fantasy Sports
item.description: Last year, Americans paid $1.7 billion to play in fantasy sports leagues. Billion!

item.title: Episode 189: Why A Dead Shark Costs $12 Million
item.description: And why a photo of steel wool that looks like a tornado costs $1,265.We wade into the economics of the art world.

item.title: Episode 489: The Invisible Plumbing Of Our Economy
item.description: Why does it take so long to send money from one bank account to another?

item.title: Episode 352: The High-Tech Cow
item.description: Behind a bucolic dairy farm lies all the roiling tension, rising inequality and economic volatility of the 21st-century economy.

item.title: Episode 488: The Secret History Of Your Cable Bill
item.description: On today's show, we answer the question every cable subscriber has asked: Why can't I just pay for the channels I want?

item.title: Episode 371: Where Dollar Bills Come From
item.description: On today's show, every single dollar bill in the world — every $20, every $100, everything — is printed on paper made at one small mill in Massachusetts. That's been the case for 130 years.

item.title: Episode 487: The Trouble With The Poverty Line
item.description: Pretty much everyone who studies poverty agrees: The way the government defines poverty is completely wrong.

item.title: Episode 369: If Teens Ran The Fed
item.description: If you're a high school student and you dream of holding the U.S. economy in the palm of your hand — if you want the power to control interest rates and to print money out of thin air — the Fed Challenge is for you.

item.title: Episode 486: Crisis Revisited
item.description: On today's show, we replay key moments from the crisis of 2008. And we ask: Are we safer now than we were five years ago?

item.title: Episode 485: What's Your Major?
item.description: The most lucrative majors lead to jobs with salaries over $100,000 a year. The least lucrative lead to salaries of around $30,000.

item.title: Episode 484: Inside The T-Shirt Factory
item.description: On today's show, we check in with our team in Bangladesh. We hear what it was like inside the factory where the Planet Money men's T-shirt was knit, dyed, cut and sewn.

item.title: Episode 483: Putting The Planet In The Planet Money T-Shirt
item.description: The cotton for the Planet Money men's T-shirt was spun into yarn in Indonesia and knit, cut and sewn into shirts in Bangladesh. On today's show, we hear from Planet Money reporters in both countries.

item.title: Episode 433: Holding A Rainforest Hostage? (Update)
item.description: A rainforest in Ecuador sits on top of hundreds of millions of barrels of oil. The government said it would leave the forest untouched — if the world paid up.

item.title: Episode 421: The Birth Of The Dollar Bill
item.description: Before the Civil War, there were 8,000 different kinds of money in the United States. And a $1 bill wasn't always worth $1.

item.title: Episode 482: Why The U.S. Keeps Sending Weapons To Egypt
item.description: U.S. military aid is unpopular among Egyptians and, increasingly, among U.S. politicians. Yet it hasn't stopped flowing.

item.title: Episode 481: The Economist's Guide To Drinking While Pregnant
item.description: On today's show, we meet a woman who is trying to bring nuance and subtlety to a world of black-and-white rules: pregnancy.

item.title: Episode 480: The Charity That Just Gives People Money
item.description: GiveDirectly is a charity that just gives money to poor people — no strings attached.

item.title: Episode 479: Behind The Label
item.description: On today's show, three stories about what how products and people get branded and what happens when you peel back the label and try to get the full story.

item.title: Episode 478: Rocky Pipkin, Private Eye Vs. The Raisin Outlaw
item.description: Today on the show, raisin farmer, Marvin Horne, is a raisin rebel, a raisin outlaw. He refused to follow the rules of the Raisin Administrative Committee and found himself under surveillance by Rocky Pipkin's detective agency. Now he's being sued by the federal government.

item.title: Episode 477: Waiting For Robot Nannies
item.description: More than half of all Japanese women quit their jobs after giving birth to their first child. That's more than double the rate in the U.S., and it's a problem for Japan's economy.

item.title: Episode 386: The Cost Of Free Doughnuts
item.description: Everybody likes free. But consider a cautionary tale about free doughnuts and the Red Cross.

item.title: Episode 476: The Return Of The Indicator*
item.description: *Not really. But sort of.

item.title: Episode 475: What Happened To Detroit's Big Plans?
item.description: On today's show, we go see what happened to all the big dreams Detroit has had over the years.

item.title: Episode 474: The North Korea Files
item.description: We got a stack of letters from American citizens who wanted to buy stuff from North Korea. On today's show, we try to figure out who sent the letters, and why.

item.title: Episode 422: Schoolhouse Rock Is A Lie (Or, How The Filibuster Ate Washington)
item.description: On today's show: Everything you need to know about the filibuster.

item.title: Episode 473: Top Of The Charts (Econ Remix)
item.description: How the top three songs in America explain the crazy transformation in the music business.

item.title: Episode 472: The One-Page Plan To Fix Global Warming
item.description: Tax carbon emissions. That's basically the whole plan.

item.title: Episode 471: The Eddie Murphy Rule
item.description: On today's show, we answer one of the most important questions in finance: What actually happens at the end of Trading Places?

item.title: Episode 286: Libertarian Summer Camp
item.description: We travel to a place where people are trying to live without government interference. A place where you can use bits of silver to buy uninspected bacon. A place where a a 9-year-old will sell you alcohol.

item.title: Episode 470: Killing Fannie Mae
