item.description: Five years after the financial crisis, the government still controls giant companies that guarantee trillions of dollars in mortgages.

item.title: Episode 469: Rhino Horns And Clean Water
item.description: On today's show: Two stories from Kenya.

item.title: Episode 468: Kid Rock Vs. The Scalpers
item.description: On today's show, we talk to Kid Rock about how he's trying to cut scalpers out of the business — and still sell cheap tickets to his shows.

item.title: Episode 467: Tires, Taxes And The Grizz
item.description: How a celebrated attempt to help one group of people ended quietly hurting a much larger group.

item.title: Episode 466: DIY Finance
item.description: Mike Smith has thousands of dollars stashed around his house in different accounts. Tamara Bullock is part of an informal savings club. Miguel Rada has a whole bank in his pocket — he takes deposits from some people and lends to others.

item.title: Episode 396: A Father Of High-Speed Trading Thinks We Should Slow Down
item.description: Thomas Peterffy's life story includes a typing robot, a proto-iPad, and a vast fortune he amassed as one of the first people to use computers in financial markets.

item.title: Episode 465: Myanmar Opens Up
item.description: On today's show, we meet two businessmen in Yangon. One is launching a startup. The other works for Coca-Cola — which is going back into Myanmar after a 60-year absence.

item.title: Episode 464: When A Poor Country Gets A Lot Richer*
item.description: *Note: The country is only getting richer on paper, but that change may make a difference in the real world.*

item.title: Episode 463: How To Get A Country To Trust Its Banks
item.description: On today's show, how do you get a country to join the world economy when the people there don't even trust their own banks.

item.title: Episode 462: When Patents Hit the Podcast
item.description: Jim Logan did not create the technology to podcast. He himself is not a modern-day podcaster. But he claims to have the patent on podcasting. On today's show, he says all the people out there podcasting today, owe him money.

item.title: Episode 461: Lawyers, Guns And Money
item.description: On today's show: Three short stories from the far flung shores of New Zealand, Ireland and New Jersey.

item.title: Episode 217: The Art Of Living At The Poverty Line
item.description: Meet a single mother who makes $16,000 a year — and who managed to fund a vacation at a Caribbean resort with an interest-free loan from one of the world's largest banks.

item.title: Episode 460: It's Hard To Do Good
item.description: A retired contractor from Colorado has spent the past two years building a school in Haiti. If he had it to do over, he tells us, he might do things differently.

item.title: Episode 459: Getting It Right
item.description: On today's show: Three short stories about trying to figure out what things are really worth. Also, an update on our t-shirt project.

item.title: Episode 458: Bangladesh's T-Shirt Economy
item.description: The Planet Money men's t-shirt will be made in part in Bangladesh.

item.title: Episode 457: Why Pink?
item.description: On today's show: What the color of the Planet Money t-shirt has to do with a painting from 1969.

item.title: Episode 456: Marijuana Arbitrage
item.description: Nearly 20 states have legalized marijuana to some degree. As it turns out, this has profound economic consequences for dealers all across the country.

item.title: Episode 224: The Cotton Wars
item.description: Meet a Brazilian who took on the world's largest superpower, a Texas cotton farmer who's tired of hearing the Brazilians complain, and a guy named Renato — a.k.a. Retaliation Master.

item.title: Episode 455: The Planet Money T-Shirt Is Finally (Almost) Here
item.description: We're making a t-shirt that tells the story of its own creation.

item.title: Episode 454: The Lollipop War
item.description: Sugar costs more in the U.S. than in the rest of the world. If you're in the candy business — if, say, you make 10 million lollipops a day — that's a big deal.

item.title: Episode 453: What Causes What?
item.description: On today's show we dive deep into the world of correlation and causation with Charles Wheelan, author of the new book,

item.title: Episode 452: How Much Should We Trust Economics?
item.description: This week, a grad student found a simple error in one of the most famous economics studies of the past several years. Should this change the way we think about economic research?

item.title: Episode 356: The Surprisingly Entertaining History Of The Income Tax
item.description: It includes multiple wars, a Supreme Court justice on his deathbed, and Donald Duck.

item.title: Episode 451: Why Some People Love Tax Day
item.description: On today's show, we look at a huge, often overlooked, surprisingly interesting corner of the tax code: The Earned Income Tax Credit.

item.title: Episode 450: Bitcoin Goes To The Moon
item.description: The value of the virtual currency is skyrocketing. Is that good or bad for bitcoin's future?

item.title: Episode 449: The Hidden Digital Wealth In Your Pocket
item.description: You can sell an old CD or used record. But what about songs from your iTunes library you no longer want? Or ebooks you've purchased? Do you have the right to resell these digital goods?

item.title: Episode 448: Coney Island Back In Business
item.description: When Hurricane Sandy struck, it devastated businesses all over New York City. One area hit particularly hard was Coney Island. We thought many businesses there were doomed after the storm, but now 5 months later, we return and find things shockingly normal.

item.title: Episode 290: North Korea's Illegal Economy
item.description: North Korea's exports include illegal drugs, counterfeit U.S. dollars, and giant statues.

item.title: Episode 447: The Con Man Who Took Down His Own Country (Then Ran For Office)
item.description: How one guy pulled off one of the largest financial scams in Kenyan history, avoided prison, re-branded himself as a man of God, and ran for a seat in parliament.

item.title: Episode 446: The Invisible 14 Million
item.description: It's come to our attention that we've missed one of the biggest stories in our economy: The startling rise in the number of people on federal disability programs.

item.title: Episode 445: Cyprus Takes Away The Security Blanket
item.description: On today's show: Why did the world freak out over the Cyprus bailout?

item.title: Episode 444: New Jersey Wine
item.description: Lou Caracciolo is trying to make high-quality wine from grapes he grows in New Jersey. But Jersey wine already has a reputation — and fancy isn't it.

item.title: Episode 443: Don't Believe The Hype
item.description: Despite all the celebration, the Dow Jones industrial average has not hit record highs recently. If you adjust for inflation, the highs just aren't as high as they seem. On today's show, we rain on the Dow's parade and explain why a lot of very smart people say we should ignore the Dow.

item.title: Episode 442: Into The Future
item.description: Driverless cars! Imported doctors! JC Penney! On today's show, we bring you three stories in one.

item.title: Episode 441: Business Secrets Of The Amish
item.description: More Amish are working in business than farming these days. But the Amish lifestyle presents a unique set of business challenges. On today's show, we travel to the The Buckeye Tool Expo to see how the Amish balance their business interests with their personal beliefs.

item.title: Episode 440: An Economic Makeover For The Catholic Church
item.description: The new Pope will have to deal with a classic business mess: a multi-billion dollar conglomerate that has stumbled and is losing money and relevance.

item.title: Episode 439: The Mysterious Power Of A Hospital Bill
item.description: For the uninsured, hospital bills are full of high prices and hard-to-decipher codes.

item.title: Episode 438: Mavericks, Monopolies And Beer
item.description: Two big companies have hatched a plan that could allegedly take money out of the pockets of ordinary Americans. And it's not just any money: it's our beer money.

item.title: Episode 437: Can Andrew Sullivan Make It On His Own?
item.description: The uberblogger recently left big media. Will readers' contributions be enough to pay his blog's eight-person staff?

item.title: Episode 436: If Economists Controlled The Borders
item.description: What would the perfect immigration system look like? We asked three economists to dream big.

item.title: Episode 435: Why Buying A Car Is So Awful
item.description: Why millions of Americans still haggle with car dealers in person, one brand at a time.

item.title: Episode 434: Dealing With Danger, Death, And Crime
item.description: Four short stories about how we deal with the threat of danger, death, and crime.

item.title: Episode 433: Holding A Rainforest Hostage?
item.description: Ecuador says it will leave its rainforest untouched — if rich countries give Ecuador billions of dollars.

item.title: Episode 267: A New Mom And The President of Iceland
item.description: On today's show, a years-long, international, multi-billion-dollar battle over one of the most boring things in finance: savings accounts.

item.title: Episode 432: The Price Of Free Breast Pumps
item.description: On today's show, we visit a breast pump boutique that has suddenly become a medical supply superstore. And we look at happens when a device goes from being something people have to pay for out of their own pocket to being free for anyone with insurance.

item.title: Episode 331: How Office Politics Could Take Down Europe
item.description: If you're looking for the beginning — and, possibly, the end — of the European financial crisis, you can find it in a single building: The Greek statistics office, at 46 Peireos Street in Athens.

item.title: Episode 320: How Fear Turned A Surplus Into Scarcity
item.description: The mystery why there was a global rice shortage and ever-increasing prices, all while countries were hoarding rice.

item.title: Episode 431: A Billion-Dollar Bet Against Weight-Loss Shakes
item.description: A hedge-fund manager says a giant company is a fraud. The company fights back. On today's show, we talk to everybody. And we consider what it means when an investor bets that a company will fail.

item.title: Episode 430: Black Market Pharmacies And The Spam Empire Behind Them
item.description: On today's show, we learn the surprising truth about what actually happens when you click that link to try and purchase herbal Viagra.

item.title: Episode 429: The Price Of Things We Love
item.description: On today's show: Three short stories about the stuff we buy — books, toys and clothes.

item.title: Episode 427: LeBron James Is Underpaid
item.description: He makes $17.5 million. He deserves twice that. On today's show, we explain why LeBron is getting hosed — and why that's probably a good thing for NBA fans, team owners, other pro players, and even LeBron himself.

item.title: Episode 297: A Big Bridge In The Wrong Place
item.description: Why they built a three-mile-long bridge when they could have built a much shorter, cheaper bridge nearby.

item.title: Episode 426: 'The Rest Of The Story' (2012 Edition)
item.description: We look back at the stories we've done in 2012 and tell you how everything turned out.

item.title: Episode 238: Making Christmas More Joyful, And More Efficient
item.description: Is there a way to make the holiday season both more efficient and more joyful? On today's Planet Money, we try to answer that question by conducting a wildly unscientific experiment. We go into a seventh-grade classroom and give a bunch of kids some small gifts — candy, raisins, fig newtons.

item.title: Episode 425: An FBI Hostage Negotiator Buys A Car
item.description: On today's show, three stories of professional negotiators using negotiation in their everyday lives.

item.title: Episode 424: How Much Is A Firefighter Worth?
item.description: On today's show, we visit a California county where firefighters asked citizens to support the fire department by paying higher taxes.

item.title: Episode 423: Just Can't Get Enough
item.description: On today's show, three stories that aired on the radio but haven't yet made it into the show: Will a $1.9 billion settlement change banks' behavior? Why the falling birthrate is bad news for kids. And the huge pay cut for doctors hiding in the fiscal cliff.

item.title: Episode 422: Schoolhouse Rock Is A Lie (Or, How The Filibuster Ate Washington)
item.description: On today's show: Everything you need to know about the filibuster.

item.title: Episode 421: The Birth Of The Dollar Bill
item.description: Before the Civil War, there were 8,000 different kinds of money in the United States. On today's show, we figure out how this world worked. And explain how the war changed everything.

item.title: Episode 420: The (Legal) Marijuana Business
item.description: On today's show, we discover one big thing that's standing in the way of marijuana entrepreneurs.

item.title: Episode 364: Should We Kill The Dollar Bill?
item.description: On today's show we go deep into the nature of money itself, and we find a surprisingly clear answer to this question.

item.title: Episode 419: Taylor Swift, Helium, A Jelly-Like Mass and The Price Of Gas
item.description: On today's show: Four Planet Money stories that aired on the radio but haven't yet made it into the podcast.

item.title: Episode 418: How The Government Set Up A Fake Bank To Launder Drug Money
item.description: One day in the early 1990s, a man walked into the U.S. embassy in Ecuador. He said he had information somebody would want to hear — information on how to go after some of the most powerful drug traffickers in the world.

item.title: Episode 417: Lance Armstrong And The Business Of Doping
item.description: On today's show, we consider a world where everybody cheats and where you can't win unless you game the regulators: Professional cycling.

item.title: Episode 416: Why The Price Of Coke Didn't Change For 70 Years
item.description: The answer includes a half a million vending machines, a 7.5 cent coin, and a company president who just wanted to get a couple lawyers out of his office.

item.title: Episode 415: Can A Poor Country Start Over?
item.description: On today's show, a North American economist and the chief of staff to a foreign president fall in love with the same idea. It's an idea they think can solve one of the oldest, hardest problems in economics: How can poor countries get richer?

item.title: Episode 128: Friend or Foe?
item.description: On today's show, Planet Money stakes out New York City's diamond, plant, and chess districts to answer a nagging question: Why do stores that all sell the same thing set up shop right next to each other?

item.title: Episode 414: After The Flood, The Backup Plan
item.description: On today's show, a flooded grocery store reveals backup plans that are usually hidden but, at moments like these, are suddenly made visible.

item.title: Episode 335: Who Killed Lard?
item.description: You rarely see lard on menus. There aren't shelves and shelves of it in every supermarket. In this country, we've sort of lost touch with the once beloved pig fat. On today's podcast, we ask — who killed lard?

item.title: Episode 413: Our Fake Candidate Meets The People
item.description: On today's show, Planet Money's economist-approved fake candidate (sort of) goes to a focus group, and creates his first ads.

item.title: Episode 411: Why Preschool Can Save The World
item.description: A robber baron who spent his billions on finger paint and changing tables. Decades-long studies that found preschool made a huge difference in the lives of poor children. And a Nobel prize-winning economist.

item.title: Episode 410: Why K-Pop Is Taking Over The World
item.description: America still makes the world's most popular music. But other countries are fighting for their share of the global market. In other worlds: Gangnam Style is not a fluke.

item.title: Episode 409: The 15-Year-Old Who Bought Two Houses
item.description: On today's show, we follow up with Willow Tufano. She just bought another house. She's trying to land a reality TV deal. And she recently wore a Pikachu costume on a trip to Alabama.

item.title: Episode 408: How To Hide Money From Your Spouse
item.description: We set up two shell companies. Now we have to figure out what to do with them.

item.title: Episode 266: A Former Crack Dealer On The Economics Of Drugs
item.description: Lots of economists write about illegal drugs. One thing missing from their papers: Actual drug dealers.

item.title: Episode 407: A Mathematician, The Last Supper And The Birth Of Accounting
item.description: Jane Gleeson-White, author of Double Entry: How the Merchants of Venice Created Modern Finance, tells us the story of how one mathematics book changed business across the planet.

item.title: Episode 406: Making Economics Sexy
item.description: We bring in real political consultants to help us plan a campaign for our fake candidate. Our goal: Sell our candidate to America by making economics sexy.

item.title: Episode 405: Cheating, Stealing And Quantitative Easing
item.description: Global trade wars. Small-time bike thieves. And what happens when the Fed talks big. On today's show, we bring you three short Planet Money stories.

item.title: Episode 404: What If You Controlled The Economy?
item.description: Fixing the economy is tough — even if you can change anything you want.

item.title: Episode 403: What Can We Do With Our Shell Companies?
item.description: And how can we meet our fake shareholder and fake director?

item.title: Episode 402: Free Heroin, And Other Ideas That Won't Get You Elected
item.description: A new tax on financial speculation. Two trillion dollars in new deficit spending. Free heroin for addicts. And other pet ideas from our panel of economists

item.title: Episode 401: Four In One
item.description: On today's show, we have four short Planet Money stories.

item.title: Episode 400: What Two Pasta Factories Tell Us About The Italian Economy
item.description: Italy is two countries — and two economies — in one.

item.title: Episode 399: Can You Patent A Steak?
item.description: Hanging out with meat inventors, cutting up chickens, and thinking about patents and innovation.

item.title: Episode 398: Obama, Ryan And Two Dead Economists
item.description: On today's show, we talk to Nicholas Wapshott, author of Keynes Hayek: The Clash That Defined Modern Economics.

item.title: Episode 397: Why The Hero Of Harrisburg Couldn't Save The City
item.description: The city of Harrisburg, Pa is $1.5 billion in debt. The man who once was in charge of the saving the city explains how it went so wrong and why it's so hard to fix it.

item.title: Episode 396: A Father Of High-Speed Trading Thinks We Should Slow Down
item.description: Thomas Peterffy's life story includes a typing robot, a proto-iPad, and a vast fortune he amassed as one of the first people to use computers in financial markets.

item.title: Episode 395: Maastricht, Marijuana And The European Dream
item.description: On today's show: Cross-border tensions in the home of the euro.

item.title: Episode 394: Why Taxpayers Pay For Farmers' Insurance
item.description: On today's show, we travel to Fairbury, Illinois. We meet three generations of farmers who tell us that, even without crop insurance, their farms would survive the drought.

item.title: Episode 393: The Building That's In Two Countries At Once
item.description: An office building on the Dutch-German border was supposed to make it easy to work in both countries. But it's also a reminder of how the European dream isn't yet a reality.

item.title: Episode 273: When The U.S. Paid Off The Entire National Debt
item.description: On today's Planet Money: The legend of the national debt. Where the debt came from, what happened the one time we paid it all off, and who came up with the whole debt-ceiling idea in the first place.

item.title: Episode 392: Keeping The Biggest Secret In The U.S. Economy
item.description: How the federal agency that compiles the monthly jobs report makes sure it doesn't leak.

item.title: Episode 391: The Anti-Addiction Pill That's Big Business For Drug Dealers
item.description: It's totally legal. So why do lots of addicts have to buy it on the street?

item.title: Episode 390: We Set Up An Offshore Company In A Tax Haven
item.description: On today's show, we dive deep into the world of offshore companies and bank accounts.We set up our own company in an offshore tax haven, and we find out where the easiest place to hide your money is.

item.title: Episode 389: Handling Other People's Money
item.description: We revisit three radio pieces, on how blind trusts work, how the European Central Bank has been flexing its muscle, and why public pension plans are about to look less healthy.

item.title: Episode 388: Putting A Price Tag On Your Descendants
item.description: It's tough to figure out how big price-tags really are when they're far in the future. But getting it wrong can have serious consequences.

item.title: Episode 387: The No-Brainer Economic Platform
item.description: On today's show: The Planet Money economic platform. Backed by the brightest minds in modern economics. Pure poison to any politician that embraces it.

item.title: Episode 386: The Cost Of Free Doughnuts
item.description: Everybody likes free, and the Internet is bursting with free services. But as companies try to figure out how to make money, consider a cautionary tale about free doughnuts and the Red Cross.

item.title: Episode 385: How Good Governments Go Bad
item.description: As citizens lose trust in their lawmakers, they jockey for special treatment — and often get it. That just compounds the problem, argues University of Chicago economist Luigi Zingales.

item.title: Episode 205: Allowance, Taxes And Potty Training
item.description: It's really, really hard to create the right kind of economic incentives — even if you're a professional economist, and all you're trying to do is teach your kids to use the toilet.

item.title: Episode 384: The Little Lie That Rocked The Banks
item.description: The most important interest rate in the world has been set by what amounts to an honor system among banks. Now it turns out at least one bank was fudging the numbers.

item.title: Episode 383: What The Health Care Decision Means For Peoples' Lives
item.description: The Supreme Court's decision will change peoples' lives. On today's show, we talk to a few of those people.

item.title: Episode 382: The Cool Kids Don't Want To Go Public
item.description: Going public doesn't hold the same allure it once did for many entrepreneurs

item.title: Episode 381: Why It's Illegal To Braid Hair Without A License
item.description: Licensing laws are supposed to protect the public. But they also raise prices and make it harder for people to find work.

item.title: Episode 380: An Austerity Wedding
item.description: Does Greece have any alternatives to austerity?

item.title: Episode 379: Does Medicaid Actually Help People?
item.description: On today's show, we talk to a Harvard economist who answers a surprisingly contentious question.

item.title: Episode 378: How Spain Created A Banking Monster
item.description: A group of people tried to fix a problem, but wound up creating a banking monster.

item.title: 377: Can Lincoln Be Cool Again?
item.description: Lincolns used to be the coolest cars in the world. On today's show, we hear how Lincoln is trying to regain its former glory.

item.title: Three Ways To Stop A Bank Run
item.description: On today's show, we walk through the three things you can do to stop a bank run — and figure out what options are left for Europe.

item.title: How To Kill A Currency
item.description: Here's what happened when a European currency union broke up after World War I.

item.title: Promises, Promises
item.description: States have promised their employees sweet retirement benefits, but haven't set aside enough money. Now, one public pension fund has filed for bankruptcy.

item.title: Why Is Syria Locked In Endless Conflict?
item.description: The answer has to do with history, politics, and a growing class of entrepreneurs who are struggling to pick a side.

item.title: Facebook: Now What?
item.description: On Friday, Facebook was valued at over $100 billion. But will the company grow into its promise? And how might it happen?

item.title: How Do You Decide Who Gets Lungs?
item.description: Unlike many scarce resources, lungs aren't for sale. So doctors have had to figure out how to allocate them.

item.title: Where Dollar Bills Come From
item.description: Every single dollar bill in the world — every $20, every $100, everything — is printed on paper made at one small mill in Massachusetts. That's been the case for 130 years.

item.title: The Real Price Of College
item.description: There's a huge gap between the sticker price for college tuition and the price students actually pay. On today's show, we try to figure out why.

item.title: If Teens Ran The Fed
item.description: If you're a high school student and you dream of holding the U.S. economy in the palm of your hand — if you want the power to control interest rates and to print money out of thin air — the Fed Challenge is for you.

item.title: In A Leaderless World, Who Wins?
item.description: On today's show, we take a world tour with Ian Bremmer to find out who thrives and who struggles in a world where no one's in charge.

item.title: A Broke Rapper, A Mystery Donor And An Empty House
item.description: On today's show, we bring you three Planet Money radio stories.

item.title: How To Make It In The Food Truck Business
item.description: On today's show, the key to succeeding in the food truck business: the perfect parking spot.

item.title: We're Headed For A Fiscal Cliff. Should We Jump?
item.description: Taxes are set to go up for most Americans next year. That's a good thing, Simon Johnson argues.

item.title: Cage Match: Coin Vs. Bill
item.description: Should we kill the dollar bill? On today's show we go deep into the nature of money itself, and we find a clear answer to this question.

item.title: Why People Do Bad Things
item.description: We talk to a guy who started out as an upstanding businessman, and went on to commit bank fraud involving millions of dollars.

item.title: Should Iceland Kill The Krona?
item.description: Does it make sense for a country the size of Staten Island to have its own currency? Iceland wants to know.

item.title: The Matzo Economy
item.description: How do you make money manufacturing a dry, bland cracker that a tiny percentage of the population eats just one week a year?

item.title: Artisanal Jerky, High-Priced Nannies And Nancy Pelosi
item.description: On today's show, we eat artisanal beef jerky, watch Nancy Pelosi raise money, and meet high priced nannies. It's is a collection of our recent radio stories.

item.title: This Man Tried To Save A Broke City
item.description: David Unkovic is a thoughtful, mild-mannered guy who was appointed to save Harrisburg, Pa. Then he disappeared.

item.title: I'm Calling To Ask For Your Contribution
item.description: On today's show, we reveal which Congressional committees are a fundraising goldmine. And which committees actually make it harder for Congressmen to raise money.

item.title: What A 16th Century Guild Teaches Us About Competition
item.description: Guilds set up a system of fines, wage ceilings, and public rebukes that would be the envy of a modern cartel.

item.title: The Surprisingly Entertaining History Of The Income Tax
item.description: It includes multiple wars, a Supreme Court justice on his deathbed, and Donald Duck.

item.title: The 14-Year-Old Who Bought A House
item.description: When a 14-year-old girl can buy a house for $12,000, is it a sign the market has bottomed?

item.title: A Former Mortgage Exec Speaks Out
item.description: A former employee describes what life was like inside a giant mortgage lender back in 2006. It's not pretty.

item.title: How Europe Saved Itself. For Now.
item.description: What the solution to Europe's debt crisis has to do with a bar on the coast of Spain.

item.title: The High-Tech Cow
item.description: Behind a bucolic dairy farm lies all the roiling tension, rising inequality and economic volatility of the 21st-century economy.

item.title: What Mormons Can Teach The IRS
item.description: Mormons are supposed to tithe 10 percent of income. But what counts as income?

item.title: China's Giant Pool Of Money
item.description: We find trillions of U.S. dollars piled up in Beijing, and ask when the money may be coming home. Also: Fake-wood flooring!

item.title: Private Equity, Explained
item.description: Today, in the second of our two-part series on private equity, we take another look at Bain Capital — the firm co-founded by Mitt Romney.

item.title: 'History Is A Battle Between Creditors And Debtors'
item.description: "Every so often these two clash, there is a crisis and the whole system is remade."

item.title: What Do Private Equity Firms Actually Do?
item.description: The story of one company purchased by Bain Capital, the private-equity firm co-founded by Mitt Romney.

item.title: Is China's Economy Genius, Or Bound For Disaster?
item.description: Has China built too much stuff with borrowed money?

item.title: Lighthouses, Autopsies And The Federal Budget
item.description: What should the government pay for? We put the question to an economist.

item.title: Genius Ideas
item.description: Oreos in China. A van-based visa business. A stock index. And a way to save Greece.

item.title: Can We Create Banks We Love?
item.description: A Stanford finance professor tells us what she thinks is wrong with banking — and how we can fix it.

item.title: Is Hosting The Super Bowl Worth It?
item.description: An economist presents the case against hosting the Super Bowl. Bonus: today's show is co-hosted by NPR's Mike Pesca.

item.title: The App Economy
item.description: Instapaper is a little app that started out as a side project. Now it's a thriving one-man business. We talk to Marco Arment, Instapaper's founder and sole employee, about the app economy.

item.title: A Former Lobbyist Tells All
item.description: On the podcast today, we get a glimpse from inside the room where money changes hands. Jimmy Williams used to lobby for the National Association of Realtors. He tells us about the ridiculous issues he's lobbied for, the flow of campaign money he supplied, and how he wants to change the system now.

item.title: Who Loaned Money To Greece, Anyway?
item.description: We found a guy — a hedge fund manager who bought Greek bonds. He explains why working out a deal on Greek debt is so complicated.

item.title: Katy Perry's Perfect Year
item.description: How much did Katy Perry's label spend on her album? And how much did they make?

item.title: Do Sanctions Work?
item.description: We talk to an economist — and hear a first-hand account of what life is like under sanctions.

item.title: The Secret Document That Transformed China
item.description: In 1978, a group of farmers in a Chinese village called Xiaogang wrote a secret contract and hid it in the roof of a mud hut. They were afraid the document might get them executed. Instead, it wound up completely transforming the Chinese economy.

item.title: Who Killed Lard?
item.description: You rarely see lard on menus. There aren't shelves and shelves of it in every supermarket. In this country, we've sort of lost touch with the once beloved pig fat. On today's podcast, we ask — who killed lard?

item.title: Who Had A Good Year?
item.description: On today's show, we visit a few people who have been doing well. There's a guy with a gold vault. A company that sells off inventories for bankrupt stores. And the king of coconut water.

item.title: 'The Rest Of The Story'
item.description: We look back at the podcasts we've done in 2011 and tell you what we got right, what we got wrong and how everything turned out in Wisconsin and Iceland. Plus, we try to to figure out why that Rihanna song that cost so much money, bombed on the radio.

item.title: Why Economists Hate Gifts
item.description: And how seventh graders solved the problem.

item.title: Jack Abramoff On Lobbying
item.description: The former lobbyist is out of prison and available for interviews. We talk to him — not about his crimes, but about the legal lobbying that goes on every day.

item.title: How Office Politics Could Take Down Europe
item.description: Or: Why a mild-mannered technocrat faces life in prison.

item.title: Dollar Coins Are Done
item.description: Earlier this year we reported on the pileup of more than a billion unwanted $1 coins in government vaults. It was the result of a law passed a few years back that ordered the mint to create coins honoring each U.S. president.Today, the White House said it will end the program.

item.title: The 'Nasty, Rotten' Airline Business
item.description: On today's podcast, we try to answer the question — why do airlines keep going bankrupt?

item.title: Europe Turns On The Bat Signal
item.description: On today's podcast, European leaders want the European Central Bank to save the currency union. But the ECB is a reluctant superhero.

item.title: A Holiday Shopping Spree
item.description: On today's show, we go shopping. We're bringing you stories about how we spend our money and what these purchases teach us about economics.

item.title: Why Does A Taxi Medallion Cost $1 Million?
item.description: Last month in New York City, two taxi medallions, the metal plates that make it legal to dive a cab in the city, sold for $1 million each. On today's show, we find out why these little pieces of metal are worth so much.

item.title: Housing, Weddings, Space, Bacon
item.description: For today's show, we've collected four Planet Money radio stories that never made it to the podcast.

item.title: A Financial Adviser Bets The House
item.description: Despite his professional training, Carl Richards got sucked into the housing boom like everybody else. Here's what he learned when he got spit out the other side.

item.title: From Harvard Economist To Casino CEO
item.description: Gary Loveman likes to say there are three things that can get you fired from Caesars: Stealing, sexual harassment and running an experiment without a control group.

item.title: Boom Town
item.description: We visit a town riding high on the gold boom in the midst of Nevada's economic disaster.

item.title: Kill The Euro, Win $400,000
item.description: We talk to a British CEO offering a prize to the person who comes up with the best plan to leave the euro.

item.title: How Fear Turned A Surplus Into Scarcity
item.description: The mystery why there was a global rice shortage and ever-increasing prices, all while countries were hoarding rice.

item.title: Inside Washington's Money Machine
item.description: On today's show, we go inside the rooms in Washington where the daily grind of campaign finance — Congressmen, lobbyists, money — takes place. At least, we try to go inside the rooms.

item.title: Keynes Vs. Hayek
item.description: We talk with Nicholas Wapshott, the author of the new book Keynes Hayek: The Clash That Defined Modern Economics. The fight over their ideas has never been more relevant.

item.title: Will Economic Growth Destroy The Planet?
item.description: Economists love economic growth. And economic news — on Planet Money and elsewhere — presents growth as a good thing. But on today's show, we ask: Is economic growth bad for the planet?

item.title: What If We Paid Off The Debt?
item.description: We got our hands on a secret government report outlining what once looked like a potential crisis: The possibility that the U.S. government might pay off its entire debt.

item.title: France And Germany, A Love Story
item.description: Germany and France are tied together by fate. On today's show, the story of France and Germany — the relationship on which the fate of Europe depends.

item.title: The Price Of Default
item.description: It seems unlikely that Greece will be able to avoid defaulting on its loans. The real question is how the default will happen — will it be clean and organized or messy and catastrophic.The nightmare scenario Greece most wants to avoid is what happened in Argentina.

item.title: The Future Of Energy
item.description: We talk with Daniel Yergin, author of a new book called The Quest. The book's heroes are the engineers and scientists of the energy world.

item.title: What Is Occupy Wall Street?
item.description: It's not a movement; it's a venue. And there's an economist who thinks it can be a model for the whole country.

item.title: The Land Boom
item.description: On today's show, we visit a place where global economic forces converge: Colo, Iowa. The price of farmland in Iowa has doubled in the past few years. We look at the broader economic picture, and ask: Is it a bubble?

item.title: How Money Got Weird
item.description: An airline, the price of oil and the financialization of the global economy. On today's show, author and former banker Satyajit Das talks about his career and the trouble with the rise of finance.

item.title: Four In One
item.description: For today's show, we collected four Planet Money radio stories that never made it to the podcast.

item.title: The Dream Of Europe And The Bailout Of Greece
item.description: "We need Greece, we need Spain, we need Italy," a cab driver told us. "It's the ending of war and it's the beginning of a new future. It's the dream for European peoples."

item.title: Toxie's Back!
item.description: Planet Money's pet toxic asset, died last year. But we learned recently that she may rise from the grave.

item.title: Germany's Painful Solution To High Unemployment
item.description: The unemployment rate in Germany is just 6 percent — and it's declining. We spent a week in Germany learning their secret recipe.

item.title: When Congress Plays Chicken
item.description: The debt-ceiling debate was a game of chicken, a political scientist says. And the supercommittee may actually work out a deal.

item.title: The Ghost That Haunts Europe's Debt Crisis
item.description: An economic disaster from 90 years ago may determine the fate of Europe's economy.

item.title: Japan's Lost Lesson
item.description: A financial crisis that began with the popping of a huge housing bubble and led to a stock market plunge and a banking crisis? That's right: We're talking about Japan in the 1990s.

item.title: Europe's Worst-Case Scenario
item.description: What's the worst that could happen? Bank runs, political riots and falling governments, for a start. Also, the end of the euro as we know it.

item.title: The Tuesday Podcast: To Solve Debt Problem, Europe Borrows More Money
item.description: Europe is borrowing money to bail out countries that got in trouble by borrowing too much money.

item.title: Norway Has Advice For Libya
item.description: With Moammar Gadhafi on the run, Libya needs to start thinking about its next big challenge — what to do with the massive amount of wealth they as a country possess in oil. Almost all countries that find oil suffer from the resource curse. But there is one notable exception — Norway.

item.title: Pizzas, Faxes And Robot Networks
item.description: Today on the podcast, we talk to some close observers of the hacker group Anonymous to find out how they operate and what they want.

item.title: Switzerland's Too Strong For Its Own Good
item.description: "The Swiss dream of isolating themselves from trouble is just an impossible dream."

item.title: The Euro's Model Student
item.description: Despite the euro's troubles, Estonia's still doing well. It has the highest growth rate and the lowest public debt of any EU country.On today's podcast, we talk to Estonia's president.

item.title: Why The World Still Needs Dollars
item.description: The global popularity of the dollar provides huge benefits for the U.S. But in the coming years, other currencies may challenge the dollar's dominance.

item.title: The Tuesday Podcast: A Big Bridge In The Wrong Place
item.description: Why did they build a three-mile-long bridge when they could have built a much shorter, cheaper bridge nearby?

item.title: Italy's A Nice Place, But The Neighborhood's Going Downhill
item.description: "It's tough to be the Italian house in the deteriorating European neighborhood," PIMCO's head of European portfolio management tells us.

item.title: The Tuesday Podcast: The Patent War
item.description: Patents are supposed to promote innovation. But in the world of software and the Internet, they're having precisely the opposite effect.

item.title: Planet Money Live
item.description: Today's podcast is a recording of the live show Alex and Adam did in DC this week. In keeping with the vibe of the nation's capital, they talk a lot about America.

item.title: The Tuesday Podcast: Would A Downgrade Matter?
item.description: One expert tells us a downgrade of America's credit rating might not be that big of a deal.

item.title: Dollar Coins In The Wild
item.description: We talk to travelers who use frequent-flier-mile credit cards to buy dollar coins and pile up miles. And we hear how the U.S. Mint is cracking down.

item.title: The Tuesday Podcast: How Much Debt Is Too Much?
item.description: On today's Planet Money, we put that question to Harvard economist Ken Rogoff. We talk to Rogoff about three countries in particular: Greece, Italy and the U.S.

item.title: North Korea's Illegal Economy
item.description: North Korea's exports include illegal drugs, counterfeit U.S. dollars and giant statues.

item.title: The Tuesday Podcast: Bitcoin
item.description: On today's Planet Money, we look at a new kind of currency that's not backed by any government.

item.title: Manufacturing The Song Of The Summer
item.description: On today's show, we tell the story of a secret battle that's been going on for more than a year: The fight to create the song of the summer, the music industry's holy grail.

item.title: Inside The Mind Of A Financial Criminal
item.description: The family behind Crazy Eddie, the electronics store, ran a massive fraud for years. Eddie's cousin Sam Antar, tells us how they did it and why it worked for so long.

item.title: Fed Behaving Dangerously, Fed President Says
item.description: Thomas Hoenig thinks the Fed is repeating mistakes of the past, keeping interest rates too low for too long. That risks creating another bubble, and another crash, he says.

item.title: Libertarian Summer Camp
item.description: We travel to a place where people are trying to live without government interference. A place where you can use bits of silver to buy uninspected bacon. A place where a a 9-year-old will sell you alcohol.

item.title: Wasting Money Making Money
item.description: On today's Planet Money, we visit an underground vault that's full of money nobody wants.

item.title: When Will The Economy Get Better?
item.description: Unemployment is still dangerously high but things are looking better for both households and companies, says economist Mark Zandi.

item.title: Why Do We Tip?
item.description: According to one theory, we tip because we feel guilty.

item.title: Inside The Credit Card Black Market
item.description: If you know the right people — and if you can get other criminals to vouch for you — you can go online and buy huge bundles of stolen credit cards. As it turns out, Planet Money knows the right people.

item.title: The Case For Preschool
item.description: Paying for poor kids to go to preschool saves the government money in the long run, an economist argues.

item.title: The Tuesday Podcast: Poor Economics
item.description: We talk to a pair of MIT economists who do real-world experiments. Their goal: Figure out the best ways to fight global poverty.

item.title: The Failure Tour Of New York
item.description: On today's Planet Money, we hit the streets with economist Tim Harford. In his new book, Adapt, Harford argues that success always starts with failure.

item.title: Fareed Zakaria's Post-American World
item.description: "We will have to share power with a whole lot of others," he says. "We will have to recognize that we can't set the standards, we can't set the agenda, we can't set the rules."

item.title: The Friday Podcast: How Many Jobs Has Scott Walker Created?
item.description: How do you figure out whether the governor created a job, or whether it would have been created without him?

item.title: Is This Man A Snuggie?
item.description: Jonathan Coulton makes a lot of money selling his music on the Internet. Is he a new model for musicians, or a lucky fluke?

item.title: The Tuesday Podcast: We Sold Gold
item.description: On today's show, we sell our gold coin. We find out whether we made or lost money — and try to figure out whether we're in a gold bubble.

item.title: The Friday Podcast: When The U.S. Paid Off The Entire National Debt
item.description: On today's Planet Money: The legend of the national debt. Where the debt came from, what happened the one time we paid it all off, and who came up with the whole debt-ceiling idea in the first place.

item.title: The Tuesday Podcast: The Finance Minister Who Robbed A Bank
item.description: Ali Tarhouni fled Libya 40 years ago and wound up teaching microeconomics at the University of Washington. Now, he's back in Libya — working as the rebels' finance minister

item.title: Medieval Economics
item.description: Knights are extortionists. Guilds knock down your house if you don't play by their rules. And you have to wait until the black death kills a third of Europe before anything changes.

item.title: The Rise And Fall Of An Internet Giant
item.description: There was a brief moment — post-Friendster, pre-Facebook — when MySpace was a big deal. How did that happen? And why was the moment so brief? The answer involves porn, spyware, and total ignorance.

item.title: A City On The Moon
item.description: How did a barren, icy island become a thriving, modern economy?

item.title: The Tuesday Podcast: How To Build A School In Haiti
item.description: Our long-running story about a school in Haiti continues. Also: A decade of U.S. home prices, sung as opera.

item.title: Do The Rich Flee High-Tax States?
item.description: The question is being debated in state capitals around the country. But when you look at the data, the answer is clear.

item.title: The Tuesday Podcast: The Island That Ran Out Of Money
item.description: During the boom, Iceland's banks got rich by going abroad. When the crisis hit, that led to a big problem.

item.title: A New Mom, Bjork's Dad And The President Of Iceland
item.description: The Planet Money team heads for Iceland. We get there just before the big election, when the people will vote decide whether to pick up the tab for mistakes bankers made before the financial crisis.

item.title: The Tuesday Podcast: A Former Crack Dealer On The Economics Of Drugs
item.description: Lots of economists write about illegal drugs. One thing missing from their papers: Actual drug dealers.

item.title: Groupon! Monty Python! Price Discrimination!
item.description: An entire show about coupons, Groupons, and the economic history of cheapskates.

item.title: The Tuesday Podcast: How Do You Create A Job?
item.description: Every politician promises to create jobs. On today's Planet Money, we ask: What does that mean?

item.title: The Friday Podcast: What Comes After Fannie And Freddie?
item.description: Should taxpayers be on the hook when people take out mortgages and don't pay them back?

item.title: Fannie And Freddie's Rise And Fall
item.description: They're two of the strangest companies in U.S. history — and their bailouts cost taxpayers more than the bailouts of AIG, GM, Citigroup, Bank of America and Goldman Sachs combined.

item.title: The Friday Podcast: Economists On Federal Funding For NPR
item.description: Should NPR receive federal funding? On today's Planet Money, we try to look at the question through the cold, hard lens of economics.

item.title: The Tuesday Podcast: Why Japan Will Bounce Back
item.description: The crisis in Japan is a horrible human tragedy. On today's Planet Money we ask: Is it also an economic disaster?

item.title: The Friday Podcast: 4th Graders Read A Credit Card Agreement
item.description: We read the thing you've never read: Your credit card agreement. And we pose the question: Does it really have to be so long and complicated?

item.title: Our Messy, Inefficient Economy
item.description: We look at the world through the eyes of Matt LeBlanc, an efficiency expert (or lean expert), who runs around with a stopwatch and equations, trying to figure out how to eliminate waste in our economy. He finds it everywhere.

item.title: China's Growth Problem
item.description: In China's latest five-year plan, the government says it wants less economic growth — and a greater focus on inequality and environmental problems.

item.title: Money Buys Happiness
item.description: An economist answers a timeless question.

item.title: The Tuesday Podcast: Discipline And Forgiveness
item.description: When borrowers don't pay, should the bank take everything? We look at different answers to the question.

item.title: The Tuesday Podcast: Inside The Great Depression
item.description: On today's Planet Money, we hear the words of ordinary man trying to come to grips with the Great Depression.

item.title: The Friday Podcast: Gold Standard, R.I.P.
item.description: On today's Planet Money: The gold standard and the Great Depression. It's the latest in our gold series.

item.title: The Tuesday Podcast: The Gold Standard
item.description: We visit the charming curmudgeon and respected finance writer James Grant. He says we should go back on the gold standard.

item.title: The Friday Podcast: Michael Lewis, Financial Disaster Travel Journalist
item.description: "At bottom, I'm not all that interested in money," Lewis tells us.

item.title: The Tuesday Podcast: Writing The Rules
item.description: As regulators write the new finance rules, we sit in on a book club and visit a public hearing full of finance-industry people.

item.title: The Friday Podcast: Egypt's Military, Inc.
item.description: We look at the Egyptian military's deep business ties to everything from dishwashers to resort hotels. And we consider how those ties influence the military's actions in the crisis.

item.title: Adam Smith, Mama's Boy
item.description: We talk with Nicholas Phillipson, the author of a new biography of Adam Smith. Besides learning about the intellectual and political world Smith inhabited, we hear a bit about the man himself.

item.title: The Friday Podcast: The Moral Of The Financial Crisis
item.description: The members of the Financial Crisis Inquiry Commission agreed on an awful lot. But they couldn't agree on the moral of the story.

item.title: The Tuesday Podcast: How Much Is A Good Teacher Worth?
item.description: A new study suggests that replacing the weakest 5 to 8 percent of teachers could add $100 trillion to the U.S. economy, over 80 years. We talk to the man behind the research, economist Eric Hanushek.

item.title: The Friday Podcast: A Meat Grinder For Fabric
item.description: On today's podcast, we consult with trade lawyer Michael Cone about where to make our t-shirt, and visit the lab where customs officials check to make sure importers are following the rules.

item.title: The Euro's Model Student
item.description: On today's show, we bring you the story of one country that played by the rules and did everything exactly the way they were supposed to. One country that worked tirelessly to gain access to the special club of the euro — Estonia.

item.title: The Friday Podcast: The Frankenstein Mortgage
item.description: The 30-year, fixed-rate mortgage -- the bedrock of American home ownership -- is a really weird loan.

item.title: Our Cute Animal Experiment, Explained
item.description: Last month, we asked you to participate in our economics experiment. On today's podcast, we dive into the results — and explain what they say about the stock market.

item.title: G-Zero
item.description: We're living in a world where there's no clear economic leadership. That creates a new set of problems.

item.title: The Tuesday Podcast: Marrying Off Spain's Troubled Banks
item.description: Meet Angel Borges, matchmaker for Spain's troubled banks. He's playing a key role in Spain's plan to merge sick banks with healthy ones.

item.title: The Wednesday Podcast: Tiny Banks, Big Problems
item.description: The fate of Spain's economy may lie in a couple dozen savings banks called cajas de ahorros. These banks hold more than 50 percent of Spanish bank deposits and many are in danger of failing.

item.title: Making Christmas More Joyful, And More Efficient
item.description: Gift-giving makes economists crazy. It's so inefficient!

item.title: The Friday Podcast: Cappuccino Reconsidered
item.description: Economists love to point out that the simplest products -- a pencil, say, or a cup of cappuccino -- are the results of an incredibly complex system.

item.title: The Tuesday Podcast: The Economics of Pursuing Your Dreams
item.description: Today on the podcast, why a horrible economy can be really good for pursuing your dreams.

item.title: The Friday Podcast: A Giant Stone Coin At The Bottom Of The Sea
item.description: A stone coin that weighs more than a small car says a lot about the meaning of money. The latest story in our gold series.

item.title: Wine, Cigars, And The Plan To Fix The Dollar
item.description: The world's biggest economies spend a summer plotting in secret, over French wine, to make the dollar worth much, much less.

item.title: The Friday Podcast: Is Europe's Bailout A Giant Shell Game?
item.description: Europe is borrowing money to bail out countries that got in trouble by borrowing too much money.

item.title: What Your $3,000 Bought In Haiti
item.description: The principal of a rural school dreamed of a new schoolhouse. It didn't work out so well.

item.title: The Tuesday Podcast: Too Big To Save
item.description: On today's Planet Money, we hear the story of how Ireland's decision to bail out its banks also had huge consequences for Europe and the U.S.

item.title: The Friday Podcast: Pietra Rivoli's T-Shirt Travels
item.description: Okay we admit it, we stole our idea to make a t-shirt and report every part of the process from Pietra Rivoli, who wrote the book, The Travels of a T-shirt in a Global Economy.

item.title: Why Gold?
item.description: What could take the place of gold? A professor of chemical engineering walks us through the periodic table of the elements.

item.title: The Friday Podcast: In Search Of The Social Security Trust Funds
item.description: There's an argument about whether or not the $2.5 trillion in the Social Security trust funds exists or not, and it centers around the use of the term "trust fund."

item.title: The Tuesday Podcast: Lighthouses, Autopsies And The Federal Budget
item.description: What should the government pay for? On today's Planet Money, we pose that question to Charlie Wheelan, author of the book Naked Economics, and recent Congressional candidate.

item.title: The Tuesday Podcast: The End Of The Housing Bust
item.description: Mark Zandi tells us what it will take for the bust to end -- and sketches out housing's profound influence on the broader economy.

item.title: The Friday Podcast: The Cotton Wars
item.description: We go to Texas and Brazil in search of cotton for the Planet Money t-shirt. We find a long-running trade war.

item.title: Stealing Our Way To A T-Shirt
item.description: It turns out it's really hard for a small team of public radio employees to turn themselves into a cutting-edge apparel company.

item.title: The Friday Podcast: The Price Of Lettuce In Brooklyn
item.description: And what it has to do with how big your raise is next year.

item.title: When A Dead-End Job Isn't A Dead End
item.description: How does a guy whose mom is a heroin addict — a guy who drops out of high school, has a kid, and starts working a minimum-wage job at a fast-food restaurant — climb out of poverty?

item.title: The Friday Podcast: Gold!
item.description: We buy gold — and find that it raises some unsettling questions. Why is our little gold coin worth $419? You can't eat it. You can't fuel your car with it. And three years ago, it was worth half as much.

item.title: Would You Rather Be Rich In 1900, Or Middle-Class Now?
item.description: Do you want a mansion and servants, or antibiotics and air conditioning?

item.title: The Art Of Living At The Poverty Line
item.description: Meet a single mother who makes $16,000 a year — and who managed to fund a vacation at a Caribbean resort with an interest-free loan from one of the world's largest banks.

item.title: The Friday Podcast: How Four Drinking Buddies Saved Brazil
item.description: Their solution for Brazil's chronic inflation: Create a currency that doesn't exist.

item.title: The Tuesday Podcast: What's Better For Helping The Poor — Greed Or Charity?
item.description: Say you want to make loans to millions of very poor women in the developing world, to help them climb out of poverty. Is it OK to raise money from rich investors, who expect to make a profit?

item.title: Toxie, R.I.P.
item.description: We are gathered here to day to commemorate the passing of Toxie, Planet Money's toxic asset.

item.title: Better Living Through Libertarianism
item.description: People could be richer, better-looking, and thinner under a libertarian government — according to a libertarian.

item.title: The Friday Podcast: We Found A Socialist!
item.description: Everybody's throwing those words around these days. But what do they really mean?

item.title: The Origin Of Toxie
item.description: We talk to a woman who bought a house during the boom — and whose mortgage wound up in our toxic asset. Can you ever spot a bubble before it bursts?

item.title: Summer's Over, Slackers. Back To School.
item.description: Deadly sea captains! Rampant pollution! And other stories economists tell on the first day of class.

item.title: Deep Read: 'Traders, Guns, And Money'
item.description: Satyajit Das, a risk consultant, who wrote the book Traders, Guns & Money, says the global financial crisis gave legislators and regulators an opportunity to address speculative activity in the deriatives market, but they missed it.

item.title: The Friday Podcast: Our Listeners Vs. The Budget Deficit
item.description: On today's Planet Money, listeners suggest ways to cut the federal budget -- and experts evaluate their suggestions.

item.title: The Tuesday Podcast: How To Spend $1,249,999,999,999.39
item.description: We go inside the Fed to find out how the central bank bought $1.25 trillion of mortgage bonds.

item.title: The Friday Podcast: Wall Street Trickery Inflated The Bubble
item.description: In the last days of the housing boom, some bankers knew there were serious problems in the mortgage market. But rather than wind their business down, they sped it up.

item.title: The Other New Banking Rules
item.description: The safety of the global financial system depends in large part on what regulators decide in round, windowless rooms in a tower in Basel, Switzerland.

item.title: Allowance, Taxes And Potty Training
item.description: It's really, really hard to create the right kind of economic incentives — even if you're a professional economist, and all you're trying to do is teach your kids to use the toilet.

item.title: The Tuesday Podcast: We're Number Two!
item.description: On today's Planet Money, we leap 30 years into the future -- when China's economy is bigger than America's.

item.title: Creating Lanes On The Information Superhighway
item.description: Since its creation the internet has been a kind of economists dream; a place without barriers, where any idea can get a hearing, where the best ideas win. But some worry the dream could be ending.

item.title: The Great Stimulus Experiment
item.description: Has the $787 billion stimulus package saved our economy?

item.title: Monopoly, A Dangerous Game?
item.description: On today's podcast, we pit economists Daniel Hamermesh and Russ Roberts against our own Alex Blumberg and Robert Smith in a heavily edited game of Monopoly to find out what economic lessons the game has to offer.

item.title: The Moonshine Stimulus
item.description: On today's podcast we explain how Prohibition, a divisive moral issue, became a celebrated business stimulus plan.

item.title: Toxie's Dark Past
item.description: A home inside Toxie, our toxic asset, is part of a $200 million mortgage scheme.

item.title: We Take Toxie On The Road
item.description: We go on the road to Florida to learn more about the people behind Toxie, Planet Money's toxic asset.

item.title: The Tuesday Podcast: Grandmother vs. Grandson, Steel-Cage Match
item.description: A 62-year-old grandmother and her 18-year-old grandson have a fake job interview with Planet Money.

item.title: Death Saves You Money
item.description: An industry study found smokers save society money — in part because they tend to die young.

item.title: The Tuesday Podcast: What The Finance Bill Doesn't Tell Us
item.description: We talk to Barney Frank, the Democratic congressman, about key questions the finance bill leaves unanswered.

item.title: LeBronomics
item.description: The criminal underworld, the nature of human happiness, and the economics of LeBron James.

item.title: The Pain-In-The-Butt Index
item.description: Meet Jonathan Bush: former ambulance driver, cousin of George W. Bush, and the CEO of athenahealth, a public company that doctors pay to manage their billing.

item.title: The Friday Podcast: Good News From Haiti
item.description: A shopkeeper left destitute by the earthquake gets a new life. And a village breaks ground on a center for washing and storing mangoes.

item.title: The Tuesday Podcast: The Billionaire And The Tire Repairman
item.description: And why, in the developing world, it's so tough for the tire repairman to get a loan.

item.title: Why A Dead Shark Costs $12 Million
item.description: And why a photo of steel wool that looks like a tornado costs $1,265.We wade into the economics of the art world.

item.title: Deep Read: 'Let Them Eat Credit'
item.description: The easy credit that led to the financial crisis was a fiscal Band-Aid, according to one economist. As economic inequality rose in the U.S., borrowing allowed people to feel richer.

item.title: The Tuesday Podcast: Tomatoes, Tradition And The Global Economy
item.description: Alex Blumberg reports from Jamaica, where low-tech tomato farmers struggle to compete.

item.title: The Friday Podcast: Too Much Lithium Is Depressing
item.description: Some economists want resource-rich countries to give money directly to the people. So far, they haven't found any takers.

item.title: The Tuesday Podcast: Haiti's Rice Market Is A Mess. Farmers' Kids Go Hungry.
item.description: The people selling rice in the market in Port-au-Prince say business is terrible. We travel to l'Artibonite, Haiti's rice country, to learn more.

item.title: Sex, Drugs And Regulation
item.description: Why do regulators often wind up partying with the regulated?

item.title: The Tuesday Podcast: The Million-Dollar Microsecond
item.description: In high-frequency trading, a millionth of a second can be worth $1 million a day.

item.title: The Friday Podcast: Can A Public Radio Shirt Be Cool?
item.description: Everybody makes a t-shirt. But we want to make a cool t-shirt. A shirt you'll wear for something other than going to the gym. And we need your help.

item.title: Is The Joyride On Wall Street Really Over?
item.description: "When this bill becomes law, the joyride on Wall Street will come to a screeching halt," Harry Reid said last week, after the Senate passed its big finance reform bill.

item.title: Zero Dollars, Zero Cents
item.description: We bought Toxie — our mortgage-backed toxic asset for $1,000 early this year. The mortgages she's made of were going sour at an alarming rate. When enough of the mortgages went bad, she would die. Right now it looks like she's in a coma.

item.title: Inside A Payday Loan Shop
item.description: Payday lenders spring up on every corner. But despite the increased competition, their rates stay the same. An economist explains.

item.title: We See Angelina's Bottom Line
item.description: There's this weird thing in the movie business: Almost all movies lose money. Except they don't, really. On today's Planet Money, Edward Jay Epstein, author of The Hollywood Economist, explains the business of movies.

item.title: Athens And The Bond Kings Of Newport Beach
item.description: In Athens, everybody has a story about the easy money that flowed when the country joined the euro. In Newport Beach, a giant bond fund decides when to make the money flow — and when to turn off the spigot.

item.title: When BB+ Is A Bad Grade
item.description: We go behind the scenes at Standard & Poor's to answer a question that's been on our mind lately: How do you rate a country?

item.title: Planet Money, Honey
item.description: A while back, CNBC anchor Maria Bartiromo trademarked her nickname: "Money Honey." There was talk of an educational show for kids, maybe a Web site. But she apparently lost interest in using the name, and she let the trademark lapse. Sensing the...

item.title: Fear And Taxes In Jamaica
item.description: In Jamaica, people don't fear the tax collector. On today's Planet Money, we hear from Kimala Bennett, an entrepreneur who decided that should change.

item.title: In Search Of The Red Tape Factory
item.description: There's an astonishing amount of bureaucracy in India. On today's Planet Money, David Kestenbaum tries to figure out why. Along with a few possible answers — legacy of colonialism, pretext for bribery, machinery of democracy — Kestenbaum brings ...

item.title: The Economics Of Bribing A Cop
item.description: David Kestenbaum talks about bribery and payoffs in India. There's the $3.30 a cab driver has to pay a cop to keep from getting a ticket. The $13 you can pay a "broker" to help you get a driver's license — no hassle!

item.title: Goldman, Answer The Question
item.description: We dive into the SEC's lawsuit against Goldman Sachs, and Goldman's emphatic arguments in its defense. And we continue our long quest to unite financial reporting with Broadway theater.

item.title: When An Asset Turns Toxic, Who You Gonna Sue?
item.description: An toxic asset — very much like our own Toxie — goes bad. And a New Jersey carpenters' union fund that bought a piece of the asset tries to figure out if there's someone to blame.

item.title: Management Secrets Of The Treadmill Video Guy
item.description: Damian Kulash is the lead singer of OK Go, the band that made that treadmill video somebody forwarded you a few years back. On today's Planet Money, Kulash talks about the sinking ship that is the music business.

item.title: New York Fed Chief, Bubble Fighter
item.description: In a rare broadcast interview, the president of the New York Fed says regulators should do more to identify and fight bubbles.

item.title: The Fed Wants To Sell You A Mall In Oklahoma
item.description: The mall is one of the many, many assets the Fed bought to bail out Bear Stearns a few years back. The assets were bundled into a special company called Maiden Lane I.

item.title: Shipping Is Underwater
item.description: So there was a big shipping bubble that inflated about the same time the housing bubble did. It grew for some similar reasons — a go-go economy, easy credit, a belief that prices never decline, etc. And, like housing, it's now turned ugly.

item.title: A Private-Equity Boss In Four-Inch Stilettos
item.description: On today's podcast, we visit with Lynn Tilton, head of a $7 billion private-equity fund. And we go inside Spiegel, the catalog company Tilton's firm bought last year.

item.title: After The Flood
item.description: A year ago, Chana Joffe-Walt looked at a bank closure and its immediate aftermath. In today's podcast, she checks in again with the main players. Turns out, the bank's chief loan officer was hiding bad loans from regulators.

item.title: Ok, He Signed It. Now What?
item.description: Millions of uninsured people will get health insurance. Millions will pay higher taxes. But the broader issue of rising health costs will remain a problem.

item.title: Did China's Central Bank Take Your Job?
item.description: Is China manipulating its currency? What does it even mean to manipulate a currency, anyway, and how does a country do it? On today's Planet Money, Alex Blumberg and David Kestenbaum explain the whole Chinese currency thing.

item.title: In Haiti, A Prime Minister's Lament
item.description: Adam Davidson and Chana Joffe-Walt interview Haiti's prime minister.

item.title: Attack Of The Special Interests!
item.description: Come Monday, we'll finally get to see what's in Chris Dodd's finance-reform bill. Two key sections we'll be keeping an eye on: derivatives reform and resolution authority.

item.title: Podcast: We Bought A Toxic Asset!
item.description: Remember toxic assets? Those weird, mortgage-backed securities that almost brought down the economy? We bought one.

item.title: Why Greece Is Stuck With The Euro
item.description: "I don't see how it's feasible to wriggle out," says Berkely economist Barry Eichengreen.

item.title: Why GDP Matters For Schoolkids
item.description: Jamaica and Barbados have taken different economic paths. Alex Blumberg visits schools in both countries to see what that means.

item.title: Podcast: Haiti's High Hopes For Vegas
item.description: An apparel trade show reveals the power of U.S. shoppers.

item.title: Why Greece Matters
item.description: A Harvard economist explains what could happen if Greece defaults on its debt.

item.title: Podcast: Why Is A Corporation A Person?
item.description: On today's podcast, Alex's story finally gets its due. We hear the full version of the story about corporate personhood pitched by Alex's dad on This American Life.

item.title: Small Business, Big Debts In Haiti
item.description: On today's podcast, sophisticated entrepreneurship among Haiti's poorest people.

item.title: Dreaming Of Plastic Crates In Haiti
item.description: On today's podcast, exporter Jean Maurice Buteau says he struggles to keep up with the demand for Haitian mangos because nearly half the fruit he buys from rural farmers arrives damaged. He says if he could only get plastic crates for the farmers ...

item.title: Our Messy, Inefficient Economy
item.description: We talk with an efficiency expert who runs around with a stopwatch figuring out how people can save time at their jobs. Sometimes people love him, sometimes not.

item.title: Starting From Scratch In Haiti
item.description: Despite the general misery and the constant funerals, Adam tells us people in Haiti are starting to talk about how to rebuild the country and the economy, maybe in a better way.

item.title: When Cinnamon Moved Markets
item.description: On today's podcast, how the ancient spice trade made our modern world.

item.title: To Stay Or Walk Away
item.description: On today's podcast, tough decisions for underwater homeowners.

item.title: An Economist Gets Stoned
item.description: Would making drugs legal make them cheaper or more expensive?

item.title: 'Yo!' Planet Money Raps
item.description: Can a rap video about economics really be cool? Pop superstar Ke$ha thinks so.

item.title: Gambling with House Money
item.description: We take a closer look at proprietary trading, since we may never hear from it again if new rules from the Obama administration take effect.

item.title: Taxing Health Care
item.description: On today's Planet Money, we put the champion of the Senate bill's "Cadillac tax" in the hot seat.

item.title: Tax Me Please
item.description: On today's podcast, why the Danes love paying taxes.

item.title: The Awesomest Economy?
item.description: On today's podcast, is Denmark a fluke or a model to be imitated?

item.title: Podcast: Your Friendly Neighborhood Bill Collector
item.description: On today's podcast, we go inside the "dirty unspoken world" of bill collectors.

item.title: John Maynard Keynes Has A Plan
item.description: On today's podcast, the next best thing to talking to John Maynard Keynes himself, a conversation with his biographer, Lord Robert Skidelsky.

item.title: Podcast: When Science And Corruption Meet
item.description: On today's podcast, an economist digs up a road.

item.title: Podcast: Ranking Corruption
item.description: On today's podcast, we talk with Jermyn Brooks of Transparency International about where the U.S. ranks on its Corruption Perceptions Index.

item.title: Podcast: Would You Bing For Free News?
item.description: On today's podcast, David Folkenflik stops by to tell us about talks between Microsoft and Rupert Murdoch that could give Microsoft's new search engine, Bing, exclusive access to list Wall Street Journal content.

item.title: Podcast: The Price Of Bias
item.description: On today's podcast, how basic economics helped make our independent press.

item.title: The Language Of Economists
item.description: On today's Planet Money, economists like to use phrase like "hybrid translog cost functions," but is this kind of jargon really necessary?

item.title: Shopping Center Economics
item.description: The second round of our Planet Money Top Chef This American Model Survivor Iron Reporter Competition.

item.title: The Possible Promise and Perils of Cap and Trade
item.description: David Kestenbaum discusses how hard it is to price carbon, a main point of debate at this week's climate conference in Copenhagen.

item.title: SEC Just Now Seeking Key Information On Meltdown
item.description: Almost three years since banks starting taking losses that led to the worst financial crisis since the Great Depression, the Securities and Exchange Commission is still asking basic questions about what happened.

item.title: Adam Smith And The Not So Invisble Hand
item.description: Remembering renown economist Paul Samuelson with the help of another Nobel Laureate, Amartya Sen.

item.title: Podcast: Your Friend or Foe?
item.description: On today's podcast, Planet Money stakes out New York City's diamond, plant, and yes, chess district.

item.title: Planet Money Goes To Copenhagen
item.description: On today's Planet Money, David Kestenbaum tells us what all the fuss in Copenhagen is about. Hint — it's green.

item.title: Podcast: The Folly Of Financial Forecasts
item.description: On today's podcast, an economist explains why economic forecasts may not be worth our time.

item.title: The 'Nine Fingered Economy'
item.description: On today's podcast, the economics of organized crime in Japan.

item.title: Podcast: Eye On Dubai
item.description: On today's podcast, Dubai has been flying high in recent years, investing billions of dollars both inside its borders and out. But news that Dubai World, a huge company owned by government, is struggling has some wondering whether the emirate's s...

item.title: Podcast: Fixing Climate Change Is Going To Cost You
item.description: On today's podcast, we try to save the world with $120.

item.title: Podcast: The Most Wasteful Time Of Year
item.description: On today's podcast, is gift giving wasting billions of dollars a year? Economist Joel Waldfogel thinks so.

item.title: Podcast: Facing Corruption In Nigeria
item.description: On today's podcast, the story behind those Nigerian email scams that ask for your help "transferring funds" into another country.

item.title: Shopping For An MRI (Outside The U.S.)
item.description: On today's Planet Money, we go in search of cheap MRIs and find them in Japan.

item.title: Podcast: China Gives Us A Pep Talk
item.description: On today's podcast, NPR correspondent Frank Langfitt headed to China a few weeks ago expecting to find people gloating about the country's rapid growth, instead he found himself being reassured about the strength of the United States.

item.title: Podcast: Looking For Criminals
item.description: On today's podcast, we discuss the acquittal of two former Bear Stearns hedge fund managers who faced charges of fraud, stemming from the collapse of funds they managed.

item.title: Podcast: Did The Cash Bring The Clunkers?
item.description: On today's podcast, Edmunds.com says the government's Cash for Clunkers program was expensive and not very successful. Naturally, the White House disagrees. They say Edmunds' analysis was flawed.

item.title: Breaking Up (Big Banks) Is Hard To Do
item.description: Economist and Planet Money regular

item.title: Podcast: We've Been Here Before
item.description: On today's Planet Money, one thing you don't want to hear during an economics crisis -- "this time is different."

item.title: Shopping For An MRI
item.description: On today's podcast, two health care facilities down the street from each other — one charges $800 for an MRI, the other $450.

item.title: Paying Doctors
item.description: On today's podcast, how Medicare pays doctors and why the current system doesn't work as well as some people think it should.

item.title: Podcast: A Marshall Plan For Africa
item.description: On today's podcast, Columbia economist and former economic adviser to the Bush administration, Glenn Hubbard, says the way to help Africa is to put foreign aid in the hands of local businesses not the government.

item.title: In The Classroom
item.description: On today's Planet Money, we try out the show on our toughest critics yet, teenagers.

item.title: GMAC's Hail Mary Pass
item.description: On today's Planet Money, GMAC is heading for a record third bailout. A Columbia economist says it has become a textbook case of the dangers of government intervention.

item.title: Can GM Ever Pay Us Back?
item.description: On today's Planet Money, we look at three answers to the nagging question of whether the public will get back the money it used to bail out GM.

item.title: Podcast: Elinor Ostrom Checks In
item.description: On today's Planet Money, a conversation with the first woman to win the Nobel prize in economics. Elinor Ostrom argues that people should organize themselves, perhaps with the help of government but not by relying on it solely.

item.title: Podcast: Economics For Monkeys
item.description: On today's Planet Money: human beings aren't the only creatures who make economic decisions. It turns out that monkeys do it, too.

item.title: Podcast: The Paradox Of Oil
item.description: On today's Planet Money, retired U.S. diplomat Herman Cohen explains why billions of dollars in oil money have done little to help the people of Angola.

item.title: Insurance For A Hedgehog
item.description: On today's Planet Money, the owners of a pet hedgehog talks about why they spent nearly $2,000 on its cancer treatments, and an economists reveals his trouble with insurance for pets or people.

item.title: The Riddle Of Minimum Wage
item.description: On today's Planet Money, a pair of economic riddles including this one: Why do cities with higher minimum wages generally have higher employment and healthier economies?

item.title: Here Comes China
