item.description: On today's Planet Money, Ian Bremmer and Kishore Mahbubani look at the inexorable rise of China.

item.title: Podcast: The Economics Of Parenting
item.description: On today's Planet Money, Brandeis professor Mick Watson explains how economics has impacted parenting styles from our early hunter-gatherer days to today's modern industrial society.

item.title: The Health Care Economist Is In
item.description: You've seen those crazy-looking medical bills, the ones with row after row of prices and treatment codes. Doctor bills are complicated enough to make you go looking for a Harvard health care economist. Which is just what we did. Today, professor J...

item.title: Podcast: Capitalism Just Keeps Churning
item.description: On today's Planet Money: During the Great Depression, people turned away from capitalism and toward ideologies like socialism. In the Great Recession, it's socialism that's on the retreat.

item.title: Podcast: Should Government Run Our Health Insurance?
item.description: On today's Planet Money, an advocate for single-payer health care and an opponent square off.

item.title: Podcast: Looking At Health Care Co-ops
item.description: On today's Planet Money, the Senate Finance Committee is weighing a $6 billion measure to set up health care cooperatives across the nation.

item.title: G20 Makes Pittsburgh Look Good
item.description: On today's Planet Money, a report from the G20 summit in Pittsburgh, with a special visit to a sudsy alternative scene.

item.title: Podcast: The Giant Pool Of Money: Where Are They Now?
item.description: On today's podcast, a year after our hour long documentary on the housing crisis, we catch up with Richard, a Marine who was facing foreclosure and Jim Finkel, a CDO manager.

item.title: Father Of The 'Public Option' Defends His Big Idea
item.description: On today's Planet Money, Yale professor Jacob Hacker says that having the government offer an insurance plan will result in better care for less money.

item.title: Revenge Of The Tariffs
item.description: On today's Planet Money, tires, chickens and messy trade relations.

item.title: Podcast: The Nightmare Of Regulatory Reform
item.description: On today's podcast, the battle over the right to regulate financial futures.

item.title: Podcast: Planet Money Live
item.description:
Alice Rivlin and Martin Bailey of the Brookings Institution at the Planet Money/Pew Charitable Trusts debate. (Katie Hayes/NPR)
var so = new SWFObject("/player/media1/mediaplayer.s...

item.title: Clipping Coupons For Health Care
item.description: On today's Planet Money, co-pay assistance cards make brand name drugs cheaper at the cash register, but they may be driving up health insurance premiums.

item.title: Podcast: Planet Money Survives First Year (Anniversary Edition)
item.description: On today's Planet Money, Adam Davidson and Alex Blumberg remember the project they meant to start and the global economic crisis that pushed that dream back for a while.

item.title: Our First Podcast: 'Brad Setser Explains The China Thing'
item.description: In Planet Money's first ever podcast, an economist revealed what keeps him up at night about Chinese investments. Talk about timing.

item.title: Economics For Medieval Chinese Peasants
item.description: On today's Planet Money, historian Kenneth Pomeranz explains why China's lower Yagtze River Valley was perhaps the best place on the planet to be poor, right up until the start of the Industrial Revolution.

item.title: The Economics Of Ticketmaster
item.description: On today's Planet Money, a listener asks why Ticketmaster charges a "convenience" fee when you print tickets you buy online. Economist Emily Oster has an answer.

item.title: Podcast: Health Insurance Is Like An All-You-Can-Eat Buffet
item.description: On today's Planet Money, a look at how health insurance skews consumer behavior by offering unlimited care.

item.title: Podcast: Rep. Barney Frank Checks In
item.description: On today's Planet Money, an interview with perhaps the single most powerful player in the drive to overhaul financial regulation, Rep. Barney Frank.

item.title: Can China Save America's Bacon?
item.description: On today's Planet Money, it may be true China's economy is recovering faster than the American one, but that doesn't make the communist nation big enough to save the world.

item.title: MySpace Was Born Of Total Ignorance. Also Porn And Spyware
item.description: On today's Planet Money, author Julia Angwin argues that the founders of MySpace wanted to recreate the chaos of a nightclub. She says it helped that they knew next to nothing at the outset.

item.title: Hear: Too Much Information
item.description: On today's Planet Money, we look at two information problems in health care. What happens when you have too little information about your doctor and too much information about your DNA?

item.title: Inside The Mind Of A Financial Criminal
item.description: On today's Planet Money, we get the inside scoop on the Crazy Eddie scam of the 70's and 80's from Sam Antar, Crazy Eddie's CFO.

item.title: Is Financial Innovation A Friend Or Foe?
item.description: On today's Planet Money, three experts debate what financial innovation really is and how much good it's done us in the last 25 years.

item.title: Your Doctor Is Like A Mechanic
item.description: On today's Planet Money, a look at one of the biggest challenges in health care: most of us patients are like drivers going to a mechanic. We don't know enough to know what we don't know, so we have to rely on someone else's judgment.

item.title: Podcast: Emily Oster Decodes The World
item.description: Some days, you just have to wonder why the world is the way it is. Emily Oster is making a career out of training the lens of economics on just that question.

item.title: Economics For 12th Century French Peasants
item.description: Medieval people lived far more constrained economic lives than we do, but had no expectations that their situations would ever improve.

item.title: Taking Health Care To The Economist
item.description: On today's Planet Money, a hospital administrator describes the challenges of controlling costs (when the doctor wants a helicopter, for instance) and an economist says no one in the system has incentives to make things cheaper.

item.title: How The Gold Standard Fueled The Great Depression
item.description: On today's Planet Money, investment manager and author Liaquat Ahamed traces the roots of the Great Depression to a series of decisions by central bankers, including a return to the gold standard.

item.title: Hear: Why The Credit Crisis Drags On
item.description: On today's Planet Money: Banks still aren't lending. Projects and purchases are still on hold. An interest rate experts explains what it will take to make the credit crisis go away.

item.title: Hear: The Pros And Cons Of Financial Innovation
item.description: On today's Planet Money, a look at the effect financial regulation can have on Wall Street creativity. On the one hand, our guest economists argue, a certain amount of regulation keeps the system running smoothly. On the other, it can choke off in...

item.title: Hear: The Latest Recession Casualty? American Power
item.description: On today's Planet Money, a look at what's become of America's role on the world stage. Analyst Ian Bremmer says other countries are recovering faster from the economic crisis and that American attention has been forced onto domestic affairs.

item.title: Bloody, Miserable Medieval Economics
item.description: On today's Planet Money, a professor of medieval history reveals what the economy was like in 12th and 13 centuries. Brutal and self-defeating only begin to describe the era of feuding guilds and tax-collecting knights.

item.title: Hear: The Goldman Sachs Interview
item.description: The Wall Street firm just turned in a glowing earnings report that includes a plan to pay out what amounts to nearly $400,000 apiece to its workers. Goldman spokesperson Lucas Van Praag answers questions about the ways Goldman got help from the go...
